revision.text:
{{use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Location map+ | France | caption = Potential targets | places = {{Location map~ | France | label = Paris | position = top | marksize = 7 | link = Paris | lat_deg = 48.8567 | lon_deg = 2.3508 }} {{Location map~ | France | label = Stade Vélodrome | position = top | marksize = 7 | link = Stade Vélodrome | lat_deg = 43.269722 | lon_deg = 5.395833 }} {{Location map~ | France | label = Civaux | position = top | marksize = 7 | link = Civaux Nuclear Power Plant | lat_deg = 46.456667 | lon_deg = 0.652778 }} }} From March to May 1998, a terror plot against the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]] in France was uncovered by European law enforcement.<ref name="LAT">{{Cite news|title=European Police Raids Target World Cup Terrorist Threat|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/may/27/sports/sp-53951|work=The Los Angeles Times|date=27 May 1998}}</ref><ref name="GlobalTerrorism1998">{{Cite journal|title=Europe Overview|journal=Patterns of Global Terrorism: 1998|url=https://fas.org/irp/threat/terror_98/europe.htm|publisher=[[Bureau of Counterterrorism|Office of the Coordinator for Counterterrorism]] (United States Department of State)|date=April 1999}}</ref> More than 100 people were arrested in seven countries as a result of the plot.<ref name="ESPN">{{Cite news|first=Simon|last=Kuper|authorlink=Simon Kuper|title=Is football facing a new age of stadium terrorism after Paris attacks?|url=http://www.espnfc.com/european-championship/74/blog/post/2715900/paris-attacks-and-a-new-age-of-stadium-terrorism|work=ESPN FC|date=18 November 2015}}</ref> Organised by the Algerian [[Armed Islamic Group of Algeria|Armed Islamic Group]] (GIA) and backed by [[al-Qaeda]] leader [[Osama bin Laden]], the plot is thought to have targeted the [[1998 FIFA World Cup Group G#England vs Tunisia|England–Tunisia match]] on 15 June 1998, and involved infiltrating the [[Stade Vélodrome]] in [[Marseille]] in order to attack players and spectators during the game, attack the hotel in [[Paris]] hosting the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States national team]], and finally hijacking an aircraft and crashing it into the [[Civaux Nuclear Power Plant]] near [[Poitiers]].<ref name="ESPN"/>
==Raids and arrests== The original suspect of the plot was French-Algerian [[Farid Melouk]], who had previously been sentenced ''[[Trial in absentia|in absentia]]'' to seven years in prison in France for his connection to the [[1995 Paris Métro and RER bombings]].<ref name="NYT">{{Cite news|title=World News Briefs; Belgians Arrest Suspect In Paris Bombings|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/06/world/world-news-briefs-belgians-arrest-suspect-in-paris-bombings.html|work=The New York Times|date=6 March 1998}}</ref><ref name="Depeche">{{Cite news|title=Bruxelles : échec au réseau du GIA|url=http://www.ladepeche.fr/article/1998/03/06/186734-bruxelles-echec-au-reseau-du-gia.html|work=La Dépêche du Midi|date=6 March 1998|language=French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Anschläge bei Fußball-WM?|url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-7838193.html|work=Der Spiegel|date=16 March 1998|language=German}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Silhouette|url=http://www.la-croix.com/Archives/1998-11-10/Silhouette-_NP_-1998-11-10-462539|work=La Croix|date=10 November 1998|language=French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Le repaire belge du terrorisme|url=http://www.lalibre.be/actu/international/le-repaire-belge-du-terrorisme-51b874c6e4b0de6db9a638e6|work=La Libre Belgique|date=14 September 2001|language=French}}</ref> Melouk had reportedly been tracked by intelligence services following his entry into [[Belgium]], where he was found to be in contact with [[Ahmed Zaoui]] and a GIA-linked [[Brussels]] mosque.<ref>Robinson, 2002, p. 172</ref> On 3 March, after two weeks of surveillance, fifty police officers stormed a house where Melouk was staying with others involved in the plot.<ref name="Robinson173">Robinson, 2002, p. 173</ref> Ten people including Swedish and Danish nationals were arrested in the 12-hour siege, amid a series of anti-terrorism raids in Belgium.<ref name="GlobalTerrorism1998"/><ref name="NYT"/><ref name="Depeche"/> Large amounts of liquid explosives were found during the raid, as well as detonators, a [[AK-47|Kalashnikov rifle]], several handguns and thousands worth of [[United States dollar|US dollars]] in cash.<ref name="Robinson173"/><ref name="FFI">{{Cite journal|first1=Brynjar|last1=Lia|authorlink1=Brynjar Lia|first2=Åshild|last2=Kjøk|date=8 August 2001|title=Islamist Insurgencies, Diasporic Support Networks, and their Host States: The Case of the Algerian GIA in Europe 1993–2000|url=https://www.ffi.no/no/Rapporter/01-03789.pdf|publisher=[[Norwegian Defence Research Establishment]] (FFI)|pages=41–43}}</ref> In addition, a large number of documents, brochures and maps relating to the World Cup were retrieved.<ref name="Robinson173"/><ref name="FFI"/> More explosives were uncovered in a follow-up raid of another house.<ref name="GlobalTerrorism1998"/>
The March raid was part of a joint security operation between Belgium, France, Sweden, Italy and the United Kingdom.<ref name="GlobalTerrorism1998"/> Despite initial Belgian claims denying links to any plot against the World Cup, the plot was later confirmed by the French counter-intelligence chief.<ref name="PBS">{{Cite news|title=Chronology: The Plots|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/front/special/cron.html|work=Frontline|publisher=PBS|date=25 January 2005}}</ref> Melouk was sentenced to 9 years in prison for charges including attempted murder.<ref name="PBS"/> In early May, eight suspected militants linked to the plot were arrested in the United Kingdom.<ref name="FFI"/><ref>Robinson, 2002, p. 180</ref>
On 26 May, nearly 100 people were detained in coordinated operations across France, Belgium, Italy, Switzerland and Germany.<ref name="LAT"/><ref name="GlobalTerrorism1998"/><ref name="PBS"/> In France, 53 men including Algerian, French and Tunisian nationals suspected of links to ex-GIA commander [[Hassan Hattab]] were detained across 43 locations, including in Marseilles, Paris, [[Lyon]] and [[Corsica]]; around 25 were arrested and charged or deported.<ref name="FFI"/><ref>Robinson, 2002, pp. 190–191</ref> Five Algerians were arrested in Germany after raids across several cities, ten in Belgium, two in Switzerland, six in Italy, and many more detained.<ref name="FFI"/><ref>Robinson, 2002, pp. 188–189</ref> French Interior Minister [[Jean-Pierre Chevènement]] said on French television after the arrests that investigators had found evidence of plots to attack the World Cup.<ref name="LAT"/> Islamist paraphernalia and $150,000 in cash were found during the raids, but no explosives or arms.<ref name="LAT"/><ref name="FFI"/> Some police sources have said that a goal of the May raids was to crush GIA support networks.<ref name="FFI"/> According to counter-terrorism magistrate [[Jean-Louis Bruguière]], the May raids were a preventive measure to protect the tournament.<ref name="GlobalTerrorism1998"/>
==Plot and aftermath== The plot involved terrorists infiltrating the Stade Vélodrome in Marseille as stadium crew, in order to attack English players and spectators during the England-Tunisia match on 15 June.<ref name="ESPN"/> Terrorists had reportedly planned to blow up the England substitute bench (targeting youngsters [[David Beckham]] and [[Michael Owen]]), shoot English players and throw grenades into the stands.<ref name="ESPN2">{{Cite news|first=Harry|last=Harris|title=England terrorist plot revealed|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/683732/england-football-team-escaped-terrorist-attack-at-1998-world-cup|work=ESPN FC|date=8 October 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|first=Laurent|last=Dubois|year=2010|title=Soccer Empire: The World Cup and the Future of France|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0tyBmBcbZIMC&lpg=PP1&hl=no&pg=PT181#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=University of California Press|page=181|isbn=9780520259287}}</ref> Other terrorists were then to storm the United States national team's hotel in Paris and attack American players watching the game there.<ref name="ESPN"/> The attacks would be followed by another group of terrorists who would hijack an aircraft and crash it into the Civaux Nuclear Power Plant near Poitiers, causing a [[nuclear meltdown]].<ref name="ESPN"/>
The details or even existence of the plot was kept secret from managers, players and the media, but was known to security including [[The Football Association|FA]] staff.<ref name="ESPN2"/> In 2009, England manager in 1998 [[Glenn Hoddle]] revealed that he had only been informed of the plot "years later", while FA Director of Communications during 1998 [[David Davies (football administrator)|David Davies]] said that he had been informed of the plot before the match by FA Head of Security Brian Hayes.<ref name="ESPN2"/> The match was otherwise marred by supporter riots in Marseilles, with British vehicles being bricked while bottles were thrown across the streets, causing police to use tear gas as large numbers of supporters were injured and arrested.<ref name="ESPN2"/>
Although organised by GIA operatives, the plot reportedly had the backing and support of al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden.<ref>{{Cite book|editor-first1=Nicholas John|editor-last1=Cull|editor-first2=David Holbrook|editor-last2=Culbert|editor-first3=David|editor-last3=Welch|first=Nicholas J.|last=Cull|year=2003|title=Propaganda and Mass Persuasion: A Historical Encyclopedia, 1500 to the Present|chapter=Osama bin Laden|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Byzv7rf6gL8C&lpg=PP1&hl=no&pg=PA222#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=ABC-CLIO|page=222|isbn=9781576078204}}</ref> According to bin Laden biographer [[Yossef Bodansky]], the World Cup plot being foiled was one of the reasons for "dormant terrorist networks" responsible for the August [[1998 United States embassy bombings]] being "reactivated". The attacks killed over 200 and wounded more than 4,000.<ref name="ESPN"/><ref>{{Cite news|first=Simon|last=Kuper|title=The World's Game Is Not Just A Game|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/26/magazine/the-world-s-game-is-not-just-a-game.html?pagewanted=all|work=The New York Times Magazine|date=26 May 2002}}</ref>
A terror plot against the [[UEFA Euro 2000]] was discovered after Dutch intelligence intercepted calls made between GIA operatives from inside French prisons.<ref name="ESPN2000">{{Cite news|title= Gun guard on French soccer stars|url=http://www.espnfc.com.au/euro2000/news/20000620frathreat.html|work=ESPN Soccernet|date=20 June 2000}}</ref> Three men were detained in French prisons as a result of the plot, and three were subsequently arrested in the Netherlands.<ref name="ESPN2000"/> One of the French prisoners detained for the plot was Adel Mechat, who served 6 years after having been arrested in Germany and extradited to France as part of the 1998 World Cup raids.<ref name="ESPN"/><ref name="ESPN2000"/>
The night before the first ever football match between France and Algeria in October 2001, police seized explosives and arrested four Islamist militants suspected of having targeted the game after a phone call had been intercepted with warnings to stay away from the [[Stade de France]]. Other items retrieved included bulletproof vests and explosives manuals.<ref name="PBS"/><ref name="Telegraph">{{Cite news|title=International Football: Seventeen held as Algerian fans invade pitch|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/international/3014255/International-Football-Seventeen-held-as-Algerian-fans-invade-pitch.html|work=The Telegraph|date=7 October 2001}}</ref> The match itself became marred with controversy, and was eventually stopped with 15 minutes left playing after Algerian fans stormed the field.<ref name="PBS"/><ref name="Telegraph"/>
==See also== * [[November 2015 Paris attacks]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Sources== * {{Cite book|first=Adam|last=Robinson|year=2002|title=Terror on the Pitch: How Bin Laden Targeted Beckham and the England Football Team|publisher=Mainstream Publishing|isbn=978-1840186130}}
{{1998 FIFA World Cup}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:World Cup terror plot, 1998}} [[Category:Al-Qaeda activities in Europe]] [[Category:Failed terrorist attempts in Europe]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents in 1998]] [[Category:Islamic terrorist incidents in the 1990s]] [[Category:Islamic terrorism in Europe]] [[Category:Islamic terrorism in Belgium]] [[Category:Islamic terrorism in France]] [[Category:Islamic terrorism in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Counter-terrorism in Belgium]] [[Category:Counter-terrorism in France]] [[Category:Police raids on Islamists]] [[Category:1998 FIFA World Cup]] [[Category:England at the 1998 FIFA World Cup]] [[Category:FIFA World Cup controversies]] [[Category:Politics and sports]] [[Category:Sports-related accidents and incidents]] [[Category:Terrorism]] [[Category:Sports controversies]] [[Category:Terrorism in Europe]]

revision.comment: added template {{About-Hugos}} to beginning of section "Awards", and deleted the text already transcluded by the template
revision.text:
{{Infobox convention | name = Denvention II, the 39th World Science Fiction Convention | image = | caption = | status = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | venue = [[Sheraton Denver Downtown Hotel|Denver Hilton Hotel]] | location = [[Denver, Colorado]] | country = United States | first = September 3–7, 1981 | organizer = | filing = non-profit | attendance = 3,792 | website = }} The '''39th World Science Fiction Convention''' ([[Worldcon]]), also known as '''Denvention II''', was held September 3–7, 1981, at the [[Sheraton Denver Downtown Hotel|Denver Hilton Hotel]] in [[Denver, Colorado]], United States. The chairmen were [[Suzanne Carnival]] and [[Don C. Thompson]]. The guests of honor were [[Clifford D. Simak]] (pro), [[C. L. Moore]] (pro), and [[Rusty Hevelin]] (fan). Extra special guest was Robert Heinlein who had been the guest of honor at the 1941 Worldcon, the first to be held in Denver. The toastmaster was [[Edward Bryant|Ed Bryant]]. Total attendance was 3,792. ==Awards== {{About-Hugos}} ===Hugo Awards=== * [[Hugo Award for Best Novel|Best Novel]]: ''[[The Snow Queen (Vinge novel)|The Snow Queen]]'' by [[Joan D. Vinge]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novella|Best Novella]]: "[[Lost Dorsai]]" by [[Gordon R. Dickson]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novelette|Best Novelette]]: "[[The Cloak and the Staff]]" by Gordon R. Dickson * [[Hugo Award for Best Short Story|Best Short Story]]: "[[Grotto of the Dancing Deer]]" by [[Clifford D. Simak]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Non-Fiction Book|Best Non-Fiction Book]]: ''[[Cosmos (book)|Cosmos]]'' by [[Carl Sagan]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation|Best Dramatic Presentation]]: ''[[The Empire Strikes Back]]'' * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Editor|Best Professional Editor]]: [[Edward L. Ferman]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Artist|Best Professional Artist]]: [[Michael Whelan]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fanzine|Best Fanzine]]: ''[[Locus (magazine)|Locus]]'', edited by [[Charles N. Brown]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Writer|Best Fan Writer]]: [[Susan Wood Glicksohn|Susan Wood]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Artist|Best Fan Artist]]: [[Victoria Poyser]] ===Other awards=== * [[Worldcon Special Award|Special Award]]: [[Edward L. Ferman]] for his effort to expand and improve the field * [[John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer]]: [[Somtow Sucharitkul]] ==See also== *[[World Science Fiction Society]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= }} ==External links== * [http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/TheLongList.html NESFA.org: The Long List] * [http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/LongListNotes.html#1981 NESFA.org: 1981 convention notes] {{S-start}} {{Succession box | before = [[38th World Science Fiction Convention]]
Noreascon Two in [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]], United States (1980) | title = [[List of Worldcons]] | years = '''39th World Science Fiction Convention'''
Denvention II in [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]], United States (1981) | after = [[40th World Science Fiction Convention]]
Chicon IV in [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]], United States (1982) }} {{S-end}} {{World Science Fiction Convention}} {{DEFAULTSORT:World Science Fiction Convention 039}} [[Category:Science fiction conventions in the United States]] [[Category:World Science Fiction Convention]] [[Category:1981 in the United States]] [[Category:1981 in Colorado]] [[Category:1982 conferences]] {{Sf-convention-stub}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Infobox concert tour | concert_tour_name = Alive Galaxy Tour | image = BIGBANG Alive tour.png | image_size = 220px | landscape = yes | image_caption = Promotional handbill for the tour | artist = [[Big Bang (South Korean band)|Big Bang]] | location = | type = | album = ''[[Alive (EP)|Alive]]'' | start_date = {{Start date|2012|3|2}} | end_date = {{end date|2013|01|27}}{{cite web | url = http://www.allkpop.com/article/2012/12/yg-entertainment-warns-against-fraudulent-ticket-sales-for-big-bangs-encore-concert-in-seoul | title = YG Entertainment warns against fraudulent ticket sales for Big Bang's encore concert in Seoul | publisher = Allkpop | date = 2012-12-29}} | number_of_legs = | number_of_shows = 41 in Asia
4 in North America
1 in South America
2 in Europe
48 in total | gross = US$73 million{{cite web|title=빅뱅 월드투어…12개국·80만명·매출 800억 (Big Bang's World Tour - 12 Countries, 800,000 Audience and 80 Billion Won Revenue)|url=http://m.mk.co.kr/index.php?year=2013&no=66641&TM=V1&PM=M0|date= January 27, 2013|archivedate=February 7, 2013 |author=Lee Sun-hee|work=Economic Daily|language=ko|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130207145934/http://m.mk.co.kr/index.php?year=2013&no=66641&TM=V1&PM=M0}} | URL = {{URL|http://alive.ygbigbang.com/}} | Misc = | last_tour = [[List of Big Bang concert tours#Love and Hope Tour|Love and Hope Tour]] (2011) | this_tour = '''Alive Galaxy Tour'''
(2012-13) | next_tour = [[Japan Dome Tour]]
(2013-14) }} The '''Alive Galaxy Tour''' (referred to as the '''Alive Tour''') was the first worldwide [[Concert#Concert tour|concert tour]] and sixth overall by South Korean boy band [[Big Bang (South Korean band)|Big Bang]]. It promotes the group's fifth Korean-language EP, ''[[Alive (EP)|Alive]]'' (as well as their fourth Japanese-language studio album of [[Alive (Big Bang album)|the same name]]), across four continents: Asia, North America, South America and Europe. The group hired choreographer and creative director [[Laurieann Gibson]] to direct the show. The tour was officially sponsored by [[Samsung Galaxy|Samsung GALAXY]]. In total, an estimated 800,000 fans worldwide attended the tour.{{cite web|last=Benjamin|first=Jeff|title=BIGBANG Reflect on Their World Tour in Exclusive Q&A|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/k-town/1549346/bigbang-reflect-on-their-world-tour-in-exclusive-qa|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=21 February 2013}} ==Background and development== [[File:Big Bang 2012.jpg|thumb|left|Big Bang performing in Singapore]] In support of their fifth extended Korean-language EP, ''[[Alive (EP)|Alive]]'' and their fourth Japanese-language studio album of [[Alive (Big Bang album)|the same name]], released February 29 and March 28, 2012, respectively, Big Bang's record label [[YG Entertainment]] announced that the group intended to hold a world tour in partnership with tour promoter [[Live Nation]], visiting Asia, North America, South America and Europe.{{cite web|url=http://www.allkpop.com/2012/02/big-bang-to-hold-world-tour-through-live-nation/|title=Big Bang to hold ‘ALIVE TOUR 2012′ around the world through Live Nation!|date=February 6, 2012|accessdate=December 4, 2012|publisher=allkpop.com|author=allkpop}} Live Nation president Alan Ridgeway stated, "We are very happy that we are working with YG Entertainment and Big Bang to show [our work] to worldwide K-pop fans." A representative for YG Entertainment followed this with, "We are working hard to hold the best concert with the best production team to equal the anticipation of the world fans who are waiting for the first concert they will get to meet Big Bang. Choreographer and creative director [[Laurieann Gibson]], famed for her work with [[Lady Gaga]], was hired as the tour's director and choreographer.{{cite web|url=http://style.mtv.com/2012/03/14/big-bang-tour/|title=Big Bang Pairs Up With Laurieann Gibson|publisher=style.mtv.com|author=Chrissy Mahlmeister|date=March 14, 2012|accessdate=December 4, 2012}} US-based visual contents company Possible Productions was hired to create the Alive tour's custom backdrops.{{cite web|url=http://www.possibleproductions.com/bigbang-american-idol-mau5trap-kids-choice-awards/|title=BIGBANG, American Idol, Mau5trap, Nicki Minaj & Kid’s Choice Awards|date=April 3, 2012|accessdate=December 4, 2012|work=possibleproductions.com|author=Figgie|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130628005255/http://www.possibleproductions.com/bigbang-american-idol-mau5trap-kids-choice-awards/|archive-date=2013-06-28|dead-url=yes|df=}} The team described the concept as a "bleak futuristic world [that could only be] saved by Big Bang."{{cite web|url=http://www.possibleproductions.com/work/bigbang-alive-galaxy-tour-2012/ |title=BIGBANG ALIVE GALAXY TOUR 2012 |date=November 2012 |accessdate=December 4, 2012 |publisher=possibleproductions.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121213024933/http://www.possibleproductions.com/work/bigbang-alive-galaxy-tour-2012/ |archivedate=December 13, 2012 |df= }} Lighting and staging, as well as overall production, was designed by Leroy Bennet.{{cite web|url=http://leroybennett.com/resume.html |title=His Résumé - 2012 |work=leroybennett.com |year=2012 |accessdate=December 4, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130209055558/http://leroybennett.com/resume.html |archivedate=February 9, 2013 |df= }} Staging and lighting alone was estimated at USD$1.3 million.{{cite web|url=http://redtix.airasia.com/events/BigBang/|title=YG ENTERTAINMENT AND LIVE NATION ENTERTAINMENT PRESENT BIGBANG Alive Galaxy Tour 2012 in Malaysia|year=2012|accessdate=December 4, 2012|publisher=redtix.airasia.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121125093522/http://redtix.airasia.com/events/BigBang/|archive-date=2012-11-25|dead-url=yes|df=}} Korean electronics brand [[Samsung]] was contracted as the tour's official sponsor, who provided electronics for the members and touring staff on the dates.{{cite web|url=http://www.soompi.com/2012/07/06/big-bang-to-collaborate-with-samsung-electronics-for-bigbang-alive-galaxy-tour-2012/|title=Big Bang to Collaborate with Samsung Electronics for "BIGBANG ALIVE GALAXY TOUR 2012″|date=July 6, 2012|accessdate=December 4, 2012|publisher=soompi.com}} This marks the first time the group has conducted a worldwide concert tour.{{cite web|url=http://www.arirang.co.kr/News/News_View.asp?nseq=137850&code=Ne2&category=2 |title=Arirang News |publisher=Arirang.co.kr |date=2012-09-28 |accessdate=2012-10-13}} ==Commercial performance== Tickets for the group's world tour, which kicked off in Seoul in March 2012, sold out faster than Live Nation had anticipated.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/10/04/bigbang-theory.html |title=BigBang theory |publisher=The Jakarta Post |date=2012-10-04 |accessdate=2012-10-13|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006234641/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/10/04/bigbang-theory.html |archivedate=October 6, 2012}} In Singapore, all tickets were sold out shortly after its on sale and a second show was immediately announced to cope with the huge ticket demand from fans. Later in Malaysia, they attracted more than 3,500 fans to queue up at the box office to fight for their tickets. In Taiwan, all 22,000 tickets of their 2 shows were sold out within just a few hours.{{cite web|url=http://njtoday.net/2012/10/01/korean-pop-group-adds-2nd-newark-show-after-original-date-sells-out/ |title=Korean Pop Group Adds 2nd Newark Show After Original Date Sells Out | njtoday.net – Everything New Jersey |work=Njtoday.net |date=2012-10-01 |accessdate=2012-10-13}} Due to strong demand from fans in the United States, two additional concert dates in both Los Angeles and New Jersey, November 2 and November 8, were added.{{cite web|url=http://ph.omg.yahoo.com/news/big-bang-adds-2-more-concert-dates-in-012009567.html |title=Big Bang Adds 2 More Concert Dates in America Due to Heavy Demand - Yahoo! OMG! Philippines |publisher=Ph.omg.yahoo.com |date=2012-10-04 |accessdate=2012-10-13}} There were initially doubts if [[T.O.P (entertainer)|T.O.P]] could perform due to an injury, but it was reported that he would continue to perform.{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/entertainment/view/1228286/1/.html |title=T.O.P to perform despite hand injury, says concert promoter |publisher=Channel NewsAsia |date=2012-09-27 |accessdate=2012-10-13}} In Japan, Big Bang became the first Korean artist to perform three Dome concerts, at the [[Tokyo Dome]], [[Osaka Dome|Kyocera Dome]], and [[Fukuoka Dome]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kpopstarz.com/articles/13890/20120910/big-bang-frist-korean-artist-performing-3-dome-concert-in-japan.htm |title=Big Bang Frist [sic] Korean Artist Performing 3-Dome Concert in Japan |publisher=KpopStarz |date= |accessdate=2012-10-13}} Ticket prices for their concert in [[Hong Kong]] were reported to cost as much as $1,680 HKD (more than 200 US Dollars){{cite web|url=http://ent.southcn.com/8/2012-09/07/content_54459077.htm |title=韩国组合BIGBANG首度来港开唱掀抢票狂潮 文娱滚动 南方网 |publisher=Ent.southcn.com |date=2012-09-07 |accessdate=2012-10-13}} The concert was held in [[Lima]], Peru on November 14, 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.rpp.com.pe/2012-10-03-big-bang-enloquece-a-sus-fanaticos-con-el-alive-galaxy-tour-noticia_527797.html |title=Big Bang enloquece a sus fanáticos con el Alive Galaxy Tour | RPP NOTICIAS |publisher=Rpp.com.pe |date= |accessdate=2012-10-13}} [[The Orange County Register]] reported that ticket prices ranged from $50 to $300 for the group's Honda Center dates in Los Angeles.{{cite web|url=https://sportylorrie.wordpress.com/2012/09/19/big-bang-alive-tour-la-nj/ |accessdate=October 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017224653/http://www.ocregister.com/entertainment/aerosmith-372155-new-comes.html |archivedate=October 17, 2013|title= New shows: Aerosmith at Staples Center, K-Pop invades O.C. }} In the UK all the tickets for the Wembley Arena show sold out within two hours of tickets going on sale, resulting in a second date being added shortly after.{{cite web|title='월드투어' 빅뱅, 英웸블리아레나 추가공연 매진|url=http://star.mt.co.kr/stview.php?no=2012121314541911708&type=3 |work=Star News |accessdate=April 1, 2017 |language=ko}} They also managed to set a London concert record for the largest crowd gathered to see a Korean act in the United Kingdom.{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.xin.msn.com/en/hallyu/big-bang-sets-london-concert-record-2#scpshrtu|title=Big Bang sets London concert record|publisher=Xin MSN Entertainment|date=2012-12-18|accessdate=2013-01-23|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214175324/http://entertainment.xin.msn.com/en/hallyu/big-bang-sets-london-concert-record-2 |archivedate=December 14, 2013}} == Critical reception == [[File:Bigbang merchandise.jpg|thumb|220px|Fan holding a Big Bang stick at a concert]] ''[[The New York Times]]'' journalist Jon Caramanica wrote that Big Bang performed more than two dozen songs wearing almost as many outfits, and in unusual setups such as "taking the stage on gilded [[Segway PT|Segways]] and lowrider bicycles" during their "short but loud American tour".{{cite news|last=CARAMANICA|first=JON|title=BigBang Performs at the Prudential Center|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/10/arts/music/bigbang-performs-at-the-prudential-center.html?_r=0|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=10 November 2012|date=November 9, 2012}} ''[[Billboard K-Town]]'' columnist Jeff Benjamin reported that concertgoers were treated to breakdancing and [[Taeyang]]'s gymnastics for a few on-stage flips during Big Bang's concert at the [[Prudential Center]] in [[New Jersey]], and described the band's concerts in America as "a success for all".{{cite web|last=Benjamin|first=Jeff|title=BIGBANG in America: Behind the Scenes With the K-Pop Boy Wonders|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/k-town/474146/bigbang-in-america-behind-the-scenes-with-the-k-pop-boy-wonders|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=16 November 2012}} Joseph Lapin from the Californian newspaper ''[[OC Weekly]]'' attended Big Bang's concert in [[Los Angeles]] and reported that the atmosphere during the show was "almost palpable". Lapin concluded, "It was nostalgic, a throwback to old-school hip-hop but with a commercial twist and a foreign reinterpretation...these boys, well, they'll be back, and they know they're going to be superstars".{{cite web|last=Lapin|first=Joseph|title=BIG BANG - Honda Center - November 3, 2012|url=http://blogs.ocweekly.com/heardmentality/2012/11/bigbang_honda_center_k-pop.php|publisher=OC Weekly|accessdate=13 December 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121211014156/http://blogs.ocweekly.com/heardmentality/2012/11/bigbang_honda_center_k-pop.php|archive-date=2012-12-11|dead-url=yes|df=}} ''[[The Guardian]]'''s music journalist Caroline Sullivan praised Big Bang for holding a "fabulous spectacle" at the [[Wembley Arena]] in [[London]]. She compared Big Bang with other Western music bands, and noted that Big Bang's edges "are crisper, the sound louder, the dancing sharper".{{cite news|last=Sullivan|first=Caroline|title=Big Bang – review|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/dec/16/big-bang-review|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=17 December 2012|location=London|date=December 16, 2012}} ''[[Radio Programas del Perú]]'' ranked the tour as the best K-pop concert in [[South America]] for 2012, beating out earlier concerts performed by [[JYJ]], [[U-Kiss]] and a [[Music Bank (TV series)]] concert at [[Chile]].{{cite web|last=Lunes|title=Concierto de Big Bang en Lima elegido el mejor en Sudamérica en 2012|url=http://www.rpp.com.pe/2012-12-31-concierto-de-big-bang-en-lima-elegido-el-mejor-en-sudamerica-en-2012-noticia_553663.html|publisher=Radio Programas del Perú|accessdate=23 January 2013}} ==Set list== {{hidden | headercss = background: #ccccff; font-size: 100%; width: 75%; | contentcss = text-align: left; font-size: 100%; width: 75%; | header = First show in Nagoya | content = {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} # "[[Gara Gara Go!]]" + "Number 1" # "Cafe" # "[[Bad Boy (Big Bang song)|Bad Boy]]" # "[[Blue (Big Bang song)|Blue]]" # "[[Love Song (Big Bang song)|Love Song]]" # "Feeling" # "Look Only At Me" + "Wedding Dress" (Taeyang) # page.title: Association for Music in International Schools

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category International music festivals to [[:Category:Music festivals staged internationally]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 January 29]].
revision.text:
{{infobox Organization | name = Association for Music in International Schools | image = Amis.png | image_border = | size = | caption = | map = | msize = | mcaption = | abbreviation = AMIS | motto = "Dedicated to the promotion of excellence in all levels of music education." | founder = Georgia Bassett | type = Non-profit Organization | status = | purpose = | headquarters = Church Farm House
North Lopham, Diss
Norfolk IP22 2LP
United Kingdom | language = English | membership = | leader_title = Chief Operating Officer | leader_name = Tim Germann | leader_title2 = Amis Consultant | leader_name2 = Georgia Bassett | leader_title3 = Executive Director | leader_name3 = Keith Montgomery | affiliations = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | budget = | website = {{URL|http://www.amis-online.org/}} | remarks = }} The '''Association for Music in International Schools''', best known as '''AMIS''', is an organization that brings together students of schools worldwide who excel in musical achievements for days of music practice and then conclude with a concert. The Association also provides professional development through an annual Music Educators' Conference. ==The Acronym== The association name ''Amis'' is also [[French language|French]] for the word ''friends''. The founders of AMIS choose this name with the purpose of the association in mind. ''Amis'' symbolizes friendships established by children all over the world who attend AMIS Festivals. AMIS' vision is to create a music festival atmosphere that is a place of learning, laughing and most importantly coming together; this is reflected in its name. Although the association AMIS is based out of the [[United Kingdom]], the association chose a French (as opposed to an English) name to represent the numerous nationalities that participate in and contribute to AMIS festivals all over the world. ==Mission statement== [[File:TwoGirlsInBlueAmisTshirt2013.jpg|thumb|left|Two girls captured wearing the 2013 European Middle School Honor Girls’ Festival Shirt.]] “The Association is an international, non-profit, [[Nonsectarian|non-sectarian]], politically neutral organization dedicated to the promotion of excellence at all levels of [[music education]]. Its objectives are to advance the education of school pupils and teachers throughout the world by developing their understanding, knowledge and appreciation of music; to advance the education of young people and their teachers in global issues and cultural diversity through the performance and study of music; to promote high standards of musical performance in school pupils of all ages and abilities throughout the world; to promote furtherance of educationally valuable music repertoire.”[http://www.amis-online.org.uk/about/mission.html AMIS Mission Statement] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080530065828/http://www.amis-online.org.uk/about/mission.html |date=May 30, 2008 }} at www.amis-online.org.uk (accessed 2008-06-18) ==AMIS Festivals== Once a year, there is a festival for each of the different categories. (See '''Festival Categories''' for list). Each festival is hosted by an AMIS Membership school, rotating between them yearly. To qualify for band, strings, and all High School auditions, students must audition by recordings, which are judged by a blind panel of music educators. Middle School Choir auditions are conducted by each participating school's teacher. The successful students travel to the host school and participate in the practice days and the final concert. The format is usually: travel Wednesday, rehearse Thursday-Saturday, concert Saturday evening, travel home Sunday. [[File:ThreeGirlsInWaterlooBelgiumAMIS.jpg|thumb|right|Three girls attending the 2013 European Middle School Honor Girls’ Choir in [[Waterloo, Belgium]].]] AMIS' member schools mainly lie in [[Europe]] and [[Asia]], with some participants in [[Africa]] (although at the moment there is one membership school that participates in festivals and hails from [[Central America]]). Founded in [[London]], AMIS slowly grew across Western Europe and now has many festivals reserved only for Asian schools. Festivals are conducted in English, though due to the participants coming from within international school populations, most students (and many teachers) speak multiple languages. Concert repertoires always include multiple languages; and concert speeches and introductions are usually held in the (festival's) host country's language in addition to English. (For example: The 2014 European Middle School Honor Girls’ Choir, hosted in [[Stavanger, Norway]], had concert services conducted in Norwegian as well as English.) ==Conductors== AMIS selects a different conductor for each festival. Often, conductors are teachers in international schools who are well respected and recommended by their peers. At the high school level, the Association contracts premiere conductors from around the world. ==Music== The repertoire style depends on the AMIS festival and the songs that the conductor wants to play. Many times, AMIS has commissioned works by authors, making the band/choir present world-premiere songs. Such authors include [[Philip Sparke]], David Brunner, Dr. Richard Prior, [[Christopher Marshall (composer)|Christopher Marshall]], and more. ==Festival Categories== AMIS presents a multitude of different yearly festivals focused on different music, instrumentation, and musicians. These are: * High School Honor Band * High School Honor Orchestra * High School Honor Mixed Choir * High School Honor Women's Choir * High School Honor Men's Choir * Honor Jazz Band and Vocal Jazz Ensemble * Solo and Ensemble Festival * European Middle School Honor Band * Asian Middle School Honor Band * Middle School Honor Mixed Choir * European Middle School Honor Girls’ Choir * Asian Middle School Honor Girls' Choir * European Middle School Honor Boys’ Choir * Asian Middle School Honor Boys’ Choir * European Middle School Honor Orchestra * Asian Middle School Honor Orchestra ==References== {{Reflist|1}} ==Administrative Team== * ''Executive Director: Keith'' Montgomery * ''Chief Operating Officer:'' Tim Germann * ''AMIS Consultant:'' Georgia Bassett * ''Board of Trustees:'' Lisa Ross, Cindy Bulteel, James Libbey, Carolyn Stock-Chapin, Rhonda Schwartz, Bill Gilfry, Bonnie Reinitzer, Julie Buell Lodi, Richard Bassett ==External links== *[http://www.amis-online.org/ AMIS Official Website] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dq_lOB5LJvg AMIS International Honor Choir 2008 - Beautiful City] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cTjNBaXDl_8&feature=related AMIS International Honor Band & Choir 2008 - Better is Peace] [[Category:Music festivals staged internationally]]

'''Atlanta Black Pride Weekend (ABPW)''' started in 1996 and is one of two officially recognized festivals for the [[African American]] [[LGBT]] community. It is held in [[Atlanta]] each year at the end of August and beginning of September (week of Labor Day holiday).<ref>[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=AT&p_theme=at&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=11B59DE9EC740528&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM "DETOURS: Black Pride parties and rallies"], ''Atlanta Journal-Constitution'', August 30, 2007</ref> It is the largest [[black gay pride]] festivals in the country <ref>[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4696068 "Celebrating Black Gay Pride"], ''National Public Radio'', 2005</ref> with approximately 100,000 people in attendance annually, the festival bills itself as the largest official black pride celebration in the world. The event plays a major part in the annual $65 million economic impact on Atlanta's economy during Labor Day weekend.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wsbtv.com/news/news/local/600000-people-expected-flood-atlanta-weekend/nnYY7/|title=Big events to bring 600,000 people to Atlanta this weekend|date=4 September 2015|website=Wsbtv.com|accessdate=25 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thegavoice.com/2017-atlanta-black-gay-pride-numbers/|title=2017 Atlanta Black Gay Pride By The Numbers|date=2017-09-02|work=Georgia Voice - Gay & LGBT Atlanta News|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en-US}}</ref> [[File:ABP2017.jpg|thumb|The 2017 Pure Heat Community Festival in [[Piedmont Park]]]]
The city of Atlanta is widely noted for being a "Black Gay Mecca" due to its highly visible black LGBT community, [[Progressivism in the United States|progressive reputation]], and vibrant [[urban area#United States|urban]] LGBT [[nightlife]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/news/2005/08/16/atlanta-new-mecca-black-gays/|title=Atlanta the new mecca for black gays|date=16 August 2005|website=Advocate.com|accessdate=25 October 2017}}</ref> Atlanta also has the largest community of black same-sex couples in the [[Southern United States|South]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/may/08/nation/na-blackgay8|title=Voice of Atlanta's Black Gays Is Emerging|last=Jarvie|first=Jenny|date=2006-05-08|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
See [http://ATLBlackPride.com ATLBlackPride.com] for a list of some annual events.
==Winter Pride== January's Martin Luther King Jr. holiday weekend is when Atlanta's first major pride event of the year is held. During this unofficial pride weekend, there are several special black gay events and celebrations for locals and visitors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.projectq.us/atlanta/lgbt_atlanta_calls_mlk_weekend_winter_pride?gid=7246|title=LGBT Atlanta calls MLK Weekend ‘Winter Pride’|website=Projectq.us|accessdate=25 October 2017}}</ref>
King's wife and Atlanta resident, [[Coretta Scott King]], was a well-known proud supporter of the black gay community. In 1998, Mrs. King publicly stated at the 25th [[Lambda Legal]] anniversary reception that she believes her late husband would have also been a supporter of [[LGBT rights in the United States|LGBT rights']].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americablog.com/2012/01/remember-the-words-of-coretta-scott-king-speaking-of-gay-civil-rights.html|title=Remember the words of Coretta Scott King, speaking of gay civil rights - AMERICAblog News|date=17 January 2012|website=Americablog.com|accessdate=25 October 2017}}</ref>
==See also== *[[African Americans in Atlanta]] *[[Atlanta Pride]] *[[Dallas Black Pride]] *[[D.C. Black Pride]] *[[Black gay pride]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.atlantaprideweekend.com/ Official website]

revision.text:
{{Infobox concert tour | concert_tour_name = Bang and Whimper 2017 – The Farewell Tour | image = Bang and Whimper 2017.jpg | image_size = 220px | image_caption = Promotional poster for the North American leg | album = | location = {{flat list| *[[Europe]] *[[North America]] }} | type = | artist = [[HIM (Finnish band)|HIM]] | start_date = {{Start date|2017|06|14}} | end_date = {{End date|2017|12|31}} | number_of_legs = 3 | number_of_shows = 51 | gross = | last_tour = Tour of the Middle Aged
(2015) | this_tour = '''Bang and Whimper 2017 – The Farewell Tour'''
(2017) | next_tour = – }} '''Bang and Whimper 2017 – The Farewell Tour''' was a concert tour by the [[Finland|Finnish]] [[gothic rock]] band [[HIM (Finnish band)|HIM]]. Originally formed in 1991, the band announced on 5 March 2017 their plans to disband following a farewell tour that same year. HIM took a break during 2016, but began work on new material at the end of the year. According to vocalist [[Ville Valo]] "the new material wasn't taking flight", and the band eventually decided to disband while still on good terms. Titled '''Bang and Whimper 2017''', the tour began on 14 June 2017 in [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]], and concluded on 31 December 2017 in [[Helsinki]], Finland, as a part of the band's annual [[Helldone|Helldone Festival]]. The tour spanned three legs, across [[Europe]] and [[North America]], with most shows being sold-out, gathering over 110 000 attendees and mostly positive reviews, with the ''[[Nottingham Post]]'' noting that HIM "truly went out with a 'bang'{{tsp}}". For the tour, the band brought out material from all their studio albums, and also played theirs first ever outdoor show in Helsinki at the [[Tuska Open Air Metal Festival]], breaking the festival's record for highest attendance on a single date. In conjunction with the tour, a special photo exhibition by [[Ville Juurikkala]], titled ''HIM: Right Here in My Eyes'', was also held at the [[Helsinki Art Museum]] and the Morrison Hotel Gallery in [[New York City|New York]], featuring new photos of the band preparing for the tour. ==Background== HIM had been on hiatus in 2016, during which time the bandmembers worked on different side projects, before regrouping at the end of the year to start work on new material with drummer Jukka "Kosmo" Kröger, who had replaced [[Gas Lipstick|Mika "Gas Lipstick" Karppinen]] in 2015.{{Cite web | title = HIM's VILLE VALO Talks New Drummer, Upcoming Studio Album| date =August 15, 2015 | website = [[Blabbermouth]] | url =http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/hims-ville-valo-talks-new-drummer-upcoming-studio-album-video/ | accessdate = 2018-03-27}} According to vocalist [[Ville Valo]]: "We felt like the new material wasn't taking flight. We got along well together, but something was lacking. The stars weren't in alignment."{{cite web|url=https://yle.fi/ylex/uutiset/him_hyvasteli_kotimaisen_metallivaen_tuskassa_ville_valo_vihjailee_sooloilusta_ja_mahdollisesta_uudesta_bandista_aion_ehka_vaihtaa_mustasta_valkoiseen/3-9701547|title =HIM hyvästeli kotimaisen metalliväen Tuskassa, Ville Valo vihjailee sooloilusta ja mahdollisesta uudesta bändistä: 'Aion ehkä vaihtaa mustasta valkoiseen'|publisher=[[YleX]] |date=2017-07-02 |accessdate=2017-07-02}} He also went on to say that: "We felt like there was nothing left to give collectively. It was fun playing the old songs, everybody got along well together, but that spark was missing."{{cite web|title = Radio Rockin Iltavuoro 2017/07/01|url =https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yz5zlgRil4o&t=27s|publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=|accessdate=2017-10-23}} In February 2017, HIM held a band meeting at a pub near their rehearsal place, where they discussed the future of the group.{{Cite web | title = HIM is dead: Ville Valo's final interview ever | date =2017-11-08| website = [[TeamRock]] | url =http://teamrock.com/feature/2017-11-08/him-is-dead-ville-valos-final-interview-ever | accessdate = 2018-01-15}} The band announced their plans to disband on 5 March 2017 via their [[Facebook]] page.{{Cite web | title = Uutispommi: HIM ilmoittaa lopettavansa uransa – jäljellä on jäähyväiskiertue, ja sitten se on siinä | date =March 5, 2017| website = Soundi | url =http://www.soundi.fi/uutiset/uutispommi-him-ilmoittaa-lopettavansa-uransa-jaljella-jaahyvaiskiertue-siina/ | accessdate = 2017-03-05}}{{Cite web | title = HIM lopettaa 26 vuoden jälkeen – massiivinen jäähyväiskiertue julki | date =March 5, 2017 | website = [[Ilta-Sanomat]] | url =http://www.is.fi/viihde/art-2000005115246.html | accessdate = 2017-03-05}} In the announcement, Valo stated: "After quarter of a century {{sic}} of love and metal intertwined we sincerely feel HIM has run its unnatural course and adieus must be said in order to make way for sights, scents and sounds yet unexplored. We completed the pattern, solved the puzzle and turned the key. Thank you." Bassist [[Mige (musician)|Mikko "Mige" Paananen]] also added: "At the end of 2017 we will be released into the wild. Before this event of great transformation we would love to offer you one last chance to experience our live performances in His Majesty's service. It shall not be a weepfest but a celebration of love metal in all its [[Lovecraftian horror|lovecraftian]] glory! See you there!" Along with the announcement, the band also revealed European dates for their farewell tour, with a North American leg being announced later in June.{{Cite web | title = HIM Announces North American Leg Of Farewell Tour; Special BLABBERMOUTH.NET Presale Available| date =2017-06-13| website =[[Blabbermouth.net]] | url =http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/him-announces-north-american-leg-of-farewell-tour-special-blabbermouth-net-presale-available/ | accessdate = 2017-06-13}} Aside from two festival appearances, no other Finnish dates were revealed, with Valo later commenting: "My deep personal wish is, that HIM's last note would be heard on the stage of the [[Tavastia Club]] on the first day of next year, but we'll see."{{cite web|title = Ville Valo: "Syvä toiveeni on, että HIMin viimeinen sävel kuullaan Tavastian lavalta" |url =https://www.mtv.fi/viihde/musiikki/artikkeli/ville-valo-syva-toiveeni-on-etta-himin-viimeinen-savel-kuullaan-tavastian-lavalta/6491214#gs.yrBG=bY |publisher=MTV |date=2017-07-03 |accessdate=2018-01-14}} In August 2017, it was announced that the band's final show would take place on [[New Year's Eve]] at the Tavastia Club as a part of the band's annual [[Helldone|Helldone Festival]].{{cite web|title = HIM TO BID FAREWELL AT TAVASTIA CLUB ON NEW YEAR’S EVE |url =https://www.tiketti.fi/HIM-to-bid-farewell-at-Tavastia-Club-on-New-Years-Eve-uutiset/10877 |publisher=Tiketti |date=2017-08-07 |accessdate=2017-08-07}} The show was quickly sold-out, so four additional Finnish dates for December were announced, all of which sold-out as well.{{cite web|title = Jäitkö ilman HIM-lippua? Jäähyväiskeikat soivat onneksi myös Helsingin Jäähallissa, Tampereella, Oulussa ja Seinäjoella |url =http://www.soundi.fi/uutiset/him-keikka-helsingin-jaahalli/ |publisher=Soundi |date=2017-08-09 |accessdate=2017-08-09}} Despite announcing the end of the band, Valo didn't rule out the possibility of reuniting in the future, stating: "The good thing about this is that there's no drama [...] So it doesn't hurt the chances." ==Production== The tour kicked off on 14 June 2017 in [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]], and continued until 31 December 2017.{{Cite web | title = HIM actuará el 16 de junio en Escenario Santander en una de sus tres fechas en España | date =December 21, 2016 | website = 20 Minutos | url =http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/2917951/0/him-actuara-16-junio-escenario-santander-sus-tres-fechas-espana/ | accessdate = 2016-12-21}} The tour ran through [[Europe]] and [[North America]], including two festival appearances in Finland, where HIM headlined the [[Tuska Open Air Metal Festival]] in [[Helsinki]] and [[Miljoona Rock]] in [[Tuuri]].{{Cite web | title = HIM, Mayhem, Suicidal Tendencies ja Brujeria Tuska Open Airiin | date =October 30, 2016 | website = Kaaoszine | url =http://kaaoszine.fi/him-mayhem-suicidal-tendencies-ja-brujeria-tuska-open-airiin/ | accessdate = 2016-11-18}}{{Cite web | title = Miljoonarock julkaisi ensi kesän esiintyjätietojaan – HIM pääesiintyjäksi, Eppu Normaali ja muita isoja kotimaisia mukana | date =January 19, 2017| website = Soundi | url =http://www.soundi.fi/uutiset/miljoonarock-julkaisi-ensi-kesan-esiintyjatietojaan-him-paaesiintyjaksi-eppu-normaali-muita-isoja-kotimaisia-mukana/ | accessdate = 2017-01-19}} HIM's appearance at Tuska marked the band's first outdoor show in their hometown of [[Helsinki]], and also broke Tuska's record for highest attendance on a single date, with 14 500 people.{{Cite web | title = Tuska Open Air uuteen kävijäennätykseen: festivaalia juhlisti kaiken kaikkiaan 37 000 vierasta| date =2017-07-03| website =Kaaoszine | url =http://kaaoszine.fi/tuska-open-air-uuteen-kavijaennatykseen-festivaalia-juhlisti-kaiken-kaikkiaan-37-000-vierasta/| accessdate = 2017-10-23}} Tuska also had its highest attendance ever that year, with 37 000 people. The band's appearance at Miljoona Rock coincided with the 50th birthday of its organizer Vesa Keskinen, with whom the band had made a deal to perform ten years prior.{{Cite web | title = Ville Valo paljastaa: "HIM teki aivan sairaan diilin Vesa Keskisen kanssa" | date =February 2, 2017 | website = [[Ilta-Sanomat]] | url =https://www.is.fi/musiikki/art-2000005075607.html | accessdate = 2018-01-15}} HIM were joined by special guests [[3Teeth]] and [[CKY (band)|CKY]] for the North American leg,{{cite web |url=https://www.altpress.com/news/entry/cky_will_be_joining_him_on_their_epic_farewell_tour |title=CKY will be joining HIM on their epic farewell tour |website=''[[Alternative Press (magazine)|Alternative Press]]'' |date=2017-08-08 |accessdate=2017-11-08 }} [[Biters (band)|Biters]] and Daxx and Roxane on select dates of the second European leg,{{Cite web | title = Biters – European Tour 2017 | date =2017-10-28| website = [[Facebook]] | url =https://www.facebook.com/BITERS/photos/a.189586578983.127122.177921643983/10156032954038984/?type=3&theater | accessdate = 2017-11-08}}{{Cite web | title = Daxx and Roxane: 'We're playing with HIM on the 19th December at the @RoundhouseLDN' | date =2017-09-08| website = [[Twitter]] | url =https://twitter.com/DaxxRoxane/status/906080841394212864 | accessdate = 2017-11-08}} and Jimsonweed for the Helldone shows, with [[The 69 Eyes]] and Delta Enigma also on select dates.{{cite web|title = Delta Enigma lämmittelee lauteet HIM:lle bändin uran toiseksi viimeisellä keikalla Tampereen Pakkahuoneella |url =http://kaaoszine.fi/delta-enigma-lammittelee-lauteet-himlle-bandin-uran-toiseksi-viimeisella-keikalla-tampereen-pakkahuoneella/ |publisher=Kaaoszine |date=2017-10-05 |accessdate=2017-10-07}} In conjunction with the band's announcement to retire, a photo exhibition by [[Ville Juurikkala]], titled ''HIM: Right Here in My Eyes'', was held at the [[Helsinki Art Museum]] in June 2017, featuring new photographs of the band rehearsing for the farewell tour.{{Cite web | title = VILLE JUURIKKALAN HIM-VALOKUVANÄYTTELY HAMIIN JA TIKETTI GALLERIAAN – OSA TUSKAN 20-VUOTISJUHLIA! | date =May 24, 2017| website = Tuska.fi | url =http://www.tuska.fi/fi/uutiset/ville-juurikkalan-him-valokuvanayttely-hamiin-ja-tiketti-galleriaan-osa-tuskan-20 | accessdate = 2017-11-01}} In November 2017, the exhibition was also held at the Morrison Hotel Gallery in [[New York City]].{{Cite web | title = HIM: 'Right Here In My Eyes' Photography Exhibition At Morrison Hotel Gallery In NYC | date =2017-11-14| website = [[Blabbermouth.net]] | url =http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/him-right-here-in-my-eyes-photography-exhibition-at-morrison-hotel-gallery-in-nyc/ | accessdate = 2017-11-15}} Also in November 2017, HIM were featured on the cover of ''[[Metal Hammer]]'', giving an exclusive interview about the band's decision to retire.{{Cite web | title = HIM Is Dead: World exclusive Ville Valo interview in the new Metal Hammer | date =2017-11-09| website = [[TeamRock]] | url =http://teamrock.com/feature/2017-11-09/him-is-dead-world-exclusive-ville-valo-interview-in-the-new-metal-hammer | accessdate = 2017-12-31}} ===Setlist=== For the setlist, HIM brought out songs from all of their studio albums, as well as their 1996 EP ''[[666 Ways to Love: Prologue]]''. The main set stayed largely the same throughout the tour, with "Stigmata Diaboli" and "It's All Tears (Drown in This Love)" having a rotating slot, while "Resurrection" was dropped from the set after the first European leg.{{cite web|url=https://www.setlist.fm/stats/songs/him-4bd6cf0a.html?song=Resurrection |title=Song Statistics: Resurrection by HIM |publisher=Setlist.fm }} "Beyond Redemption" also made an appearance in the setlist for the first time in thirteen years at the Summit Music Hall in [[Denver]].{{cite web|url=https://www.setlist.fm/setlist/him/2017/summit-music-hall-denver-co-5be3033c.html |title=HIM Setlist at Summit Music Hall, Denver, CO, USA |publisher=Setlist.fm }} "Stigmata Diaboli" and "Resurrection" also hadn't been performed live since 2002 and 2004 respectively.{{cite web|url=https://www.setlist.fm/setlist/him/2017/razzmatazz-barcelona-spain-1be4b92c.html |title=HIM Setlist at Razzmatazz, Barcelona, Spain |publisher=Setlist.fm }} "When Love and Death Embrace" and a cover of [[Billy Idol]]'s "[[Rebel Yell (song)|Rebel Yell]]" were the major mainstays of the encore, with "[[Pretending (HIM song)|Pretending]]" and "Razorblade Kiss" occasionally appearing as well.{{cite web|url=https://www.setlist.fm/setlist/him/2017/pepsi-center-wtc-mexico-city-mexico-2be36cae.html |title=HIM Setlist at Pepsi Center WTC, Mexico City, Mexico |publisher=Setlist.fm }} "Sleepwalking Past Hope" also appeared twice on the encore, at the [[House of Blues]] in [[Anaheim, California|Anaheim]] and [[Lake Buena Vista, Florida|Lake Buena Vista]] respectively.{{cite web|url=https://www.setlist.fm/setlist/him/2017/house-of-blues-lake-buena-vista-fl-7be35288.html |title=HIM Setlist at House of Blues, Lake Buena Vista, FL, USA |publisher=Setlist.fm }}{{cite web|url=https://www.setlist.fm/setlist/him/2017/house-of-blues-anaheim-ca-13e30179.html |title=HIM Setlist at House of Blues, Anaheim, CA, USA |publisher=Setlist.fm }} {{hidden | headercss = background: #ccccff; font-size: 100%; width: 55%; | contentcss = text-align: left; font-size: 100%; width: 55%; | header = Setlist from 14 June 2017 at Razzmatazz, [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]] | content = *"[[Bye Bye Love (The Everly Brothers song)|Bye Bye Love]]" (Intro tape) #"[[Buried Alive by Love]]" #"Heartache Every Moment" #"Your Sweet Six Six Six" #"Resurrection" #"[[The Kiss of Dawn]]" #"[[The Sacrament (song)|The Sacrament]]" #"Tears on Tape" #"[[Wings of a Butterfly]]" #"Gone With the Sin" #"Stigmata Diaboli" #"[[Wicked Game]]" #"Bleed Well" #"[[Killing Loneliness]]" #"Poison Girl" #"It's All Tears (Drown in This Love)" #"[[Heartkiller]]" #"[[Join Me in Death]]" #"In Joy and Sorrow" #"Right Here in My Arms" #"[[The Funeral of Hearts]]" '''Encore''' #
  • "[[Rebel Yell (song)|Rebel Yell]]" #"When Love and Death Embrace" }} {{hidden | headercss = background: #ccccff; font-size: 100%; width: 55%; | contentcss = text-align: left; font-size: 100%; width: 55%; | header = Setlist from 31 December 2017 at [[Tavastia Club]], [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]]{{cite web|url=https://www.setlist.fm/setlist/him/2017/tavastia-helsinki-finland-1be1cd9c.html |title=HIM Setlist at Tavastia, Helsinki, Finland |publisher=Setlist.fm }} | content = *"Bye Bye Love" (Intro tape) #"Buried Alive by Love" #"Heartache Every Moment" #"Your Sweet Six Six Six" #"The Kiss of Dawn" #"The Sacrament" #"Tears on Tape" #"Wings of a Butterfly" #"Gone With the Sin" #"Soul on Fire" #"Wicked Game" #"Killing Loneliness" #"Poison Girl" #"Bleed Well" #"Heartkiller" #"Join Me in Death" #"Stigmata Diaboli" #"In Joy and Sorrow" #"Right Here in My Arms" #"The Funeral of Hearts" '''Encore''' #
  • "Rebel Yell" #"When Love and Death Embrace" }} ==Reception== [[File:HIM - Helsinki Ice Hall 2017 (15).jpg|thumb|300px|right|HIM performing at the [[Helsinki Ice Hall]] on 27 December 2017]] The tour was generally well received, with the ''[[Nottingham Post]]'' stating that HIM "truly went out with a 'bang'".{{Cite web | title = HIM at Rock City, Nottingham on their farewell tour – review and photos | date =December 16, 2017| website = ''[[Nottingham Post]]'' | url =http://www.nottinghampost.com/whats-on/music-nightlife/him-rock-city-nottingham-farewell-936297 | accessdate = 2017-12-22}} Most shows were sold-out, with the tour gathering an audience of over 110 000 people.{{Cite web | title = HIM-yhtyeen maailmanvalloitus päättyi Lontooseen, mutta takaportti jää auki: Ehkä me soitetaan Ruisrockissa 2024, kun rahat on loppu | language = Finnish | date =December 20, 2017 | website = ''[[Helsingin Sanomat]]'' | url =https://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/art-2000005496946.html | accessdate = 2017-12-22}} ''Soundi'' gave praise to the band's appearance at [[Tuska Open Air Metal Festival|Tuska]], commending their stage-presence and overall performance,{{Cite web | title = Keikkareportaasi: Karismaa, ei sirkustemppuja – HIM ensimmäistä ja viimeistä kertaa Tuskassa | language = Finnish | date =July 4, 2017| website = ''Soundi'' | url =https://www.soundi.fi/keikat/keikkareportaasi-karismaa-ei-sirkustemppuja-ensimmaista-ja-viimeista-kertaa-tuskassa/ | accessdate = 2017-12-22}} which was echoed by ''[[Helsingin Sanomat]]'', who touted the show as "meeting all expectations".{{Cite web | title = HIMin keikka Tuskassa täytti kaikki odotukset | language = Finnish | date =July 2, 2017| website = ''[[Helsingin Sanomat]]'' | url =https://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/konserttiarvostelu/art-2000005276161.html | accessdate = 2017-12-22}} Praise was also given to the tour's setlist, which ''[[Loudwire]]'' stated "couldn’t have been more perfectly crafted".{{Cite web | title = HIM KISS NORTH AMERICA GOODBYE WITH STUNNING NEW YORK CITY GIG | date =November 18, 2017| website = ''[[Loudwire]]'' | url =http://loudwire.com/him-kiss-north-america-goodbye-new-york-city/#photogallery-1=4 | accessdate = 2017-12-22}} Valo's vocal performance was well received, which ''Loudwire'' touted as sounding "perfect the entire night" at the band's show in [[New York City|New York]]. ''Soundi'' echoed this, describing Valo's performance at Tuska as "possibly the best the man has ever sounded". The rest of the band were also praised, with ''[[Etelä-Suomen Sanomat]]'' noting how all members got their respective moments to shine, singling out [[Linde Lindström]]'s solo in "[[Wicked Game]]" as a particular highlight.{{Cite web | title = Konserttiarvio: HIM käy riemulla kohti loppuaan – Helsingin Jäähallissa nähtiin keskiviikkoiltana vapautunut Ville Valo | language = Finnish | date =| website = ''[[Etelä-Suomen Sanomat]]'' | url =https://www.ess.fi/uutiset/kulttuurijaviihde/art2426187 | accessdate = 2017-12-30}} The overall atmosphere of the shows was described as "celebratory", "exciting", yet "solemn",{{Cite web | title = Finnish Goth-Metal Band HIM Bids Farewell to U.S. With New York City Tour Stop | date =November 18, 2017| website = ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' | url =https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/8039473/finnish-goth-metal-band-him-farewell-tour-new-york-city-concert | accessdate = 2017-12-22}} with ''[[The Guardian]]'' concluding their review by stating that "in an era saturated with cash-in reunions it is refreshing to see a band devil-sign off on their own eccentric terms".{{Cite web | title = HIM review – fond and florid farewell for Finnish metal monsters | date =December 15, 2017| website = ''[[The Guardian]]'' | url =https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/dec/15/him-review-fond-and-florid-farewell-for-finnish-metal-monsters | accessdate = 2017-12-22}} ''Ilta-Sanomat'' felt similarly, commenting how HIM "never became [[Journeyman (boxing)|journeymen]], whose only fuel for touring was just nostalgia", noting how their show at the [[Helsinki Ice Hall]] featured a band with "more fury and character than most performers ever".{{Cite web | title = Kommentti: HIM lopettaa huipulla – yhtye ei ole jäähyväiskiertueellaan säälittävä kehäraakki | language = Finnish | date =| website = ''[[Ilta-Sanomat]]'' | url =https://www.is.fi/viihde/art-2000005504601.html | accessdate = 2017-12-31}} While the tour was mostly well received, ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' noted technical difficulties hindering the band's show in [[New York City|New York]], while ''[[Ilta-Sanomat]]'' gave a less-favorable review for the band's appearance at [[Miljoona Rock]], describing it as lacking "atmosphere" and Valo "looking bored".{{Cite web | title = Näkökulma: Eturivissä haukoteltiin avoimesti – HIM:n viimeinen festarikeikka ei sujunut odotusten mukaan | language = Finnish | date =July 14, 2017| website = ''[[Ilta-Sanomat]]'' | url =https://www.is.fi/viihde/art-2000005291788.html | accessdate = 2017-12-22}} MTV felt similarly, likening Valo's performance at the Helsinki Ice Hall to a "karaoke night", and stating that "at the Ice Hall we saw a HIM that won't be missed in the slightest".{{Cite web | title = Kommentti: Ville Valo oli illan suurin häviäjä – Jäähallissa nähtiin HIM, jota ei tule tippaakaan ikävä | language = Finnish | date =| website = MTV | url =https://www.mtv.fi/viihde/musiikki/artikkeli/kommentti-ville-valo-oli-illan-suurin-haviaja-jaahallissa-nahtiin-him-jota-ei-tule-tippaakaan-ikava/6710662 | accessdate = 2017-12-30}} ''Dead Press!'' also gave the band's show in [[Manchester]] a mixed review, noting how the band seemed to be "going through the motions", and ultimately called the show "mostly a yawn orgy, and unfortunately a bittersweet farewell."{{Cite web | title = LIVE: HIM @ ACADEMY, MANCHESTER (16/12/2017) | language = | date =| website =''Dead Press!'' | url =http://www.deadpress.co.uk/77216/live-him-academy-manchester-2017 | accessdate = 2017-12-30}} Ticket sales for the tour's final five dates also caused some controversy. Tickets for the [[Helldone]] shows were named specific to the buyer, and attendees were required to show matching identification upon entry to the venue.{{Cite web | title = Fanit raivostuivat: HIM-yhtyeen jäähyväiskeikkojen lipunmyynti suututtaa – erikoisella käytännöllä yritetään estää trokaaminen | language = Finnish | date =| website = ''[[Ilta-Sanomat]]'' | url =https://www.is.fi/musiikki/art-2000005489039.html | accessdate = 2017-12-31}} If several tickets had been purchased to a large party and the buyer was unable to attend, ticket offices did not provide the option of changing the name, only allowing resale of the tickets back to the seller. This policy was taken in order to reduce [[Ticket resale|scalping]], with organizer Tiina Vuorinen commenting: "HIM has always been surrounded by a ticket-scam-mentality, and that's why this policy has been in effect for years at previous Helldone shows." ==Tour dates== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! style="width:140px;"|Date ! style="width:150px;"|City ! revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Use South African English|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox play | name = Boesman and Lena | image = | image_size = | caption = | writer = [[Athol Fugard]] | characters = Boesman;
Lena;
Outa | mute = | setting = [[Eastern Cape]], [[South Africa]] | date of premiere = 1969 | country of origin = [[South Africa]] | original language = English | series = | subject = | genre = | web = }} '''''Boesman and Lena''''' is a small-cast [[Play (theatre)|play]] by [[South Africa]]n playwright [[Athol Fugard]], set in the [[Swartkops]] mudflats outside the playwright's native [[Port Elizabeth]] in the [[Eastern Cape]],[http://www.encyclopedia.com/arts/educational-magazines/boesman-lena "Boesman & Lena"], Encyclopedia.com. that shows the effect of [[apartheid]] on a few individuals, featuring as characters a "[[Coloured]]" man and woman walking from one shanty town to another. ==Background== In common with much of Fugard's other work, the play focuses on non-white characters and includes an element of social protest. ''Boesman and Lena'' was inspired by an incident in 1965 when Fugard was driving down a rural road in South Africa. He noticed an old lady walking along the road in the boiling-hot sun, miles from anywhere, and offered her a lift. She was overcome and cried with gratitude. She told him that her husband had just died and she was walking to another farm. If Fugard had not stopped, she would have spent the night on the side of the road.{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Boesman and Lena / Introduction | date= | publisher= | url =http://www.enotes.com/boesman/ | work =enotes | pages = | accessdate =6 March 2008 | language = }} (It was a common practice in [[apartheid]] South Africa for farmers to evict worker's families when the worker died.) What struck Fugard was that the woman was in pain and suffering but was far from defeated. This inspired him to write the play. ==Notable productions== The play premiered in 1969 at the [[Rhodes University]] Little Theatre in [[Grahamstown]], South Africa. Fugard himself played the part of Boesman, Lena was played by [[Yvonne Bryceland]] and Glynn Day, a white actor, played the part of Outa in [[blackface]]. On 22 June 1970, the US premiere, an acclaimed [[off-Broadway]] at the [[Circle in the Square Theatre|Circle in the Square Downtown]], starred [[James Earl Jones]] and [[Ruby Dee]],Mel Gussow, [https://www.nytimes.com/1970/06/22/archives/james-earl-jones-sighs-for-boesman-and-lena.html?_r=0 "James Earl Jones Sighs For ‘Boesman and Lena’"], ''The New York Times'', 22 June 1970. directed by [[John Berry (film director)|John Berry]] (who would also direct a film version, also titled ''Boesman and Lena'', in 2000).{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/12/01/arts/john-berry-82-stage-film-director-who-exiled-himself-during-blacklisting-1950-s.html|title=John Berry, 82, Stage and Film Director Who Exiled Himself During Blacklisting of 1950's|author=Ralph Blumenthal|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1 December 1999|accessdate=}} Running for 205 performances until 24 January 1971, the production won [[Obie Awards]] for Best Foreign Play, Distinguished Direction, and Best Performance by an Actress.[http://www.lortel.org/Archives/Production/1199 "Boesman and Lena"] at Circle in the Square Downtown, Lortel Archives, Internet Off-Broadway Database. A revival of the play by the [[Manhattan Theater Club]], directed by the playwright himself (and starring [[Keith David]], [[Lynne Thigpen]] and Tsepo Mokone), was produced at [[New York City Center]] in 1992, when the ''[[New York Times]]'' review by [[Frank Rich]] said: "Whether or not you get to the Manhattan Theater Club's revival of 'Boesman and Lena,' you can always see another, informal version of its drama day or night on a Manhattan sidewalk or subway platform or vacant lot. Athol Fugard's image of an itinerant homeless couple sheltered within their scrap-heap possessions and awaiting the next official eviction is now as common in New York City, among other places, as it was in the South Africa where he set and wrote his play in the late 1960's. Even at the time of its premiere, 'Boesman and Lena' was recognized as a universal work that might speak to audiences long after apartheid had collapsed. But who would have imagined that the universality would soon prove so uncomfortably literal?"Frank Rich, [https://www.nytimes.com/1992/01/30/theater/review-theater-boesman-and-lena-fugard-s-sad-wanderers-with-intimations-of-now.html "Review/Theater: Boesman and Lena; Fugard's Sad Wanderers, With Intimations of Now"], ''The New York Times'', 30 June 1992. Writing in ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine [[John Simon (critic)|John Simon]] concluded: "This is an important play, no less so since conditions in South Africa have somewhat improved: The misery may now be as much existential as social. Outside oppressors add to it, but we carry oppression within us."John Simon, "Benoit & Marcelle & Henri & Angelique" in ''New York'', Vol. 25, no. 6, 10 February 1992, pp. 86–87. This production won a [[Lucille Lortel Award]] for Outstanding Revival and an Obie Award for Thigpen's performance, as well as being nominated as Best Revival of a Play for an [[Outer Critics Circle Award]].[http://www.lortel.org/Archives/Production/1318 "Boesman and Lena"] at New York City Center-Stage I, Lortel Archives, Internet Off-Broadway Database. ==Film versions== Two film adaptations of Fugard's play, both of the same title — one directed by [[Ross Devenish]], starring Fugard and Bryceland, and the other directed by John Berry, starring [[Danny Glover]] and [[Angela Bassett]] — were released in 1973[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0071234/?ref_=nm_flmg_dr_17 "Boesman and Lena (1973)"], IMDb. and 2000,[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0197311/ "Boesman and Lena (2000)"], IMDb. respectively. ==Publication== ''Boesman and Lena'' was first published in 1971 by [[Samuel French]] ({{ISBN|9780573606205}}), and has since appeared in other editions of Fugard's works: ''Boesman and Lena and Other Plays'' ([[Oxford University Press]], 1978; {{ISBN|978-0192812421}}), ''Three Port Elizabeth Plays: The Blood Knot: Hello and Goodbye: Boesman and Lena'' (Oxford University Press, 1974, {{ISBN|978-0192113665}}; Viking Press, 1974; {{ISBN|978-0670709298}}), and ''Blood Knot and Other Plays including Boesman And Lena and Hello And Goodbye'' ([[Theatre Communications Group]], 1991; {{ISBN|978-1559360203}}). ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * Alvin Klein, [https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/10/nyregion/theater-boesman-prophetic-and-brilliant.html?pagewanted=1 "'Boesman,' Prophetic and Brilliant" (review)], ''The New York Times'', 10 December 1989. * [http://www.kdhx.org/index.php?Itemid=364&id=1907&option=com_content&task=view Black Rep review] * [http://www.media-imdb.com/title/tt0071234/ IMDb film entry for the 1973 version] * [http://www.media-imdb.com/title/tt0197311/combined IMDb film entry for the 2000 version] {{Plays by Athol Fugard}} {{John Berry (film director)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boesman And Lena}} [[Category:South African plays]] [[Category:1969 plays]] [[Category:Literary duos]] [[Category:Plays set in South Africa]] [[Category:South African plays adapted into films]] [[Category:Plays based on actual events]] [[Category:Plays about apartheid]] [[Category:South African films]] [[Category:Plays by Athol Fugard]] [[Category:Films shot in South Africa]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2011}} {{infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Brutal Assault | image = Brutal Assault 2012 main stages.jpg | caption = Brutal Assault 2012. The two main stages are built against the walls of [[Josefov Fortress]]. | landscape = | location = [[Josefov Fortress]], [[Jaroměř]], Czech Republic | years_active = 1996–present | founders = Vladan, Martin "Shindy" Brzobohatý, Tomáš Fiala{{cite web|url=http://www.metalopolis.net/art_interviews.asp?id=4816|title=BRUTAL ASSAULT - Zmrzlinové poháre a palacinky pre IMMORTAL (rozhovor so Shindym)|publisher=Metalopolis.net|accessdate=2012-11-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312060332/http://www.metalopolis.net/art_interviews.asp?id=4816|archivedate=2012-03-12|df=}} | dates = Early August | genre = [[Extreme metal]], [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]], [[hardcore punk]], [[experimental music|experimental]] | URL = | website = {{url|http://brutalassault.cz/en/}} }} '''Brutal Assault''' is an [[Open-air concert|open-air]] [[extreme metal]] [[rock festival|festival]] that takes place in the 18th-century army fortress [[Josefov Fortress|Josefov]], located in [[Jaroměř]], Czech Republic. It is held each August early in the month from Wednesday until Saturday. The festival started in 1996, originally focused on [[grindcore]]. For many years, it was a small event with mainly Czech and Slovak bands performing. It changed location several times and grew into a large event by 2006, when over 7,000 people attended the festival in [[Svojšice (Pardubice District)|Svojšice]]. After moving to Josefov, attendances grew further to 15,000 in 2012{{cite web|title=Brutal Assault byl vyprodaný, přijelo 15 tisíc metalistů|url=http://kultura.idnes.cz/brutal-assault-01s-/hudba.aspx?c=A120813_085356_hudba_ob|website=iDnes|accessdate=9 June 2014}} and the festival has operated two alternating main stages since. Currently, Brutal Assault features artists that perform all forms of extreme metal, including some of the genre's most prominent figures, as well as artists with dark and intense styles from genres outside of [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] such as [[punk rock]], [[experimental rock]] and [[electronic music|electronic]]. The festival motto is: "Against violence and intolerance".{{Cite web|url=http://brutalassault.cz/en/directions/|title=Directions for the festival visitors {{!}} Brutal Assault Festival|website=brutalassault.cz|access-date=2016-08-15}} ==Location== [[File:Jaroměř Josefov from air K2 -3.jpg|thumb|left|[[Jaroměř]] from air, with the fortress visible at the bottom of the picture.]] [[File:Josefstadt-festung.JPG|thumb|right|A view inside of the fortress.]] Brutal Assault takes place in [[Josefov Fortress|Josefov]], an army fortress built between 1780 and 1787 by Emperor [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph II]] on the left bank of the [[Elbe]] and [[Metuje|Mettau]] rivers near [[Jaroměř]]. The two main stages are built against the fortress walls. ===Safety=== Stealing from the tents and bodies of drunk visitors is common at Brutal Assault.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} Guests are advised to keep their valuables in safe places (e.g. deposit boxes provided by the festival organizers for a fee, locked inside the trunk of a car, etc.). The festival area at Brutal Assault in Josefov is near a hill, which can be difficult to navigate. Nicknamed "the hill of death", it becomes muddy and slippery after rain.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} The hill can be walked around, however, and the site is fully accessible to the handicapped. == 2014 == [[File:Venom (Brutal Assault 2014).jpg|thumb|right|[[Venom (band)|Venom]] performing as the headliner of the first day at the 2014 event.]] The nineteenth annual festival was held from Wednesday 6 August to Saturday 9 August 2014. It was headlined by [[Slayer]], [[Amon Amarth]], [[Satyricon (band)|Satyricon]], [[Venom (band)|Venom]], [[Bring Me the Horizon]], [[Children of Bodom]], [[Devin Townsend]] and [[Down (band)|Down]]. Three bands were announced but eventually had to be cancelled: [[Strife (band)|Strife]], [[Arsonists Get All the Girls]] and [[Gorguts]] (who have instead been announced for Brutal Assault 2015). {| class="wikitable" | colspan="4" align="center" | '''Double Main Stage''' |- !Wednesday !Thursday !Friday !Saturday |- |valign="top" align="center" width=235| Suburban Terrorist
