{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Peeks Toronto Caribbean Carnival |image = Peeks TCC 145x.png |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = TCC{{cite web |url=http://torontocaribbeancarnival.com/ |publisher=Toronto Caribbean Carnival |title=Toronto Caribbean Festival}} |motto = |formation = 1967 |extinction = |type = Cultural festival |status = Active, non-profit |purpose = Celebration of Caribbean heritage |headquarters = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada |location = 19 Waterman Avenue Suite 200, Toronto, Ontario |region_served = |membership = |language = [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] |leader_title = CEO |leader_name = VACANT |main_organ = |parent_organization = Festival Management Committee |affiliations = [[City of Toronto]], Toronto Mas Bands Association [https://web.archive.org/web/20120622084107/http://www.torontomasbands.com/], Ontario Steelpan Association |num_staff = 12 |num_volunteers = 1,000+ |budget = {{CAD|1.2 million}} |website =torontocarnival.ca |remarks = }} The '''Peeks Toronto Caribbean Carnival''', formerly and still commonly called '''Caribana''', is a festival of [[Caribbean]] culture and traditions held each summer in the city of [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada. It is a Caribbean [[Carnival]] event, that has been billed as [[North America]]'s largest street festival,[https://rove.me/to/toronto/toronto-caribbean-carnival-or-caribana Toronto Caribbean Carnival or Caribana] frequented by over 1.3 million visitors each year for the festival's final parade and an overall attendance of 2 million.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/32391351|title=Caribana, the greatest celebration|last=1954-|first=Foster, Cecil,|date=1995|publisher=Ballantine Books|others=Schwarz, Chris, 1948–2007.|isbn=0345398165|edition=Souvenir|location=Toronto|oclc=32391351}} The entire event, which is one of the first [[Caribbean Carnival]]s along with those in [[Labor Day Carnival|New York City]], [[Notting Hill Carnival|Notting Hill]] and [[Boston]] to be held outside of the Caribbean region, brings in over one million people to Toronto and over $400 million into Ontario's economy, annually.{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/opinion/editorials/article/803506|title=The Caribana success story|last=|first=|work=[[Toronto Star]]|date=May 3, 2010|accessdate=June 1, 2010}} == Cultural significance == The festival was introduced to Canada by immigrants from the [[Caribbean]]. It follows a Carnival format, particularly following the [[Trinidad and Tobago Carnival]], but also influenced by the street dancing and masquerading in costume found on every Caribbean island such as [[John Canoe]] in Jamaica, [[Crop Over]] in Barbados, and other similar festivals in Cuba, Haiti, and the Dominican Republic. The Carnival participants say that this event is very important for preserving and expressing their Caribbean identity.{{cite web|url=https://www.macleans.ca/society/why-torontos-caribbean-carnival-is-still-important-50-years-later/|title=Why Toronto's Caribbean Carnival is still important 50 years later|publisher=Maclean's|accessdate=July 9, 2018}} A commonality between these cultural events is a cultural legacy that is born out of slavery.{{Cite news|url=http://spacing.ca/toronto/2017/07/31/caribana-meaning-ordered-chaos/|title=Caribana and the meaning of ordered chaos - Spacing Toronto|date=2017-07-31|work=Spacing Toronto|access-date=2018-03-11|language=en-US}} Caribana also taps into the legacy of the [[Canadian Negro Women's Organization]]'s pre-Lenten Calypso Carnival celebrations{{Cite web|url=http://archives.library.yorku.ca/exhibits/show/pushingbuttons/black--caribbean-community/caribana-buttons|title=York University Libraries {{!}} Clara Thomas Archives & Special Collections online exhibits {{!}} Caribana buttons · The Jean Augustine Political Button Collection|website=archives.library.yorku.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-21}} and the centuries-long [[Black Canadians|Black Canadian]] tradition of [[Emancipation Day]] parades. Celebrations such as Calypso Carnivals and the Emancipation parades made a lot of room for Caribbean to exist as such a large observance of black Canadian pride. Canada’s Carnival traditions owe a lot to Canadian Negro Women’s Association, or CANEWA, who were one of the first groups to make space for the commemoration of black history within Ontario. Although a majority of the members did not have Caribbean roots, from 1952-1964 CANEWA produced, funded, and hosted annual one-day celebrations of Caribbean culture through food, dance, and music called the Calypso Carnivals. These carnivals began as fundraisers for scholarships in order for black students to attend recently desegregated schools in southern Ontario. Emancipation Day Parades began to celebrate the liberation of slaves throughout the Americas and were largely observed around the same time as the Calypso Carnivals. The founders of this parade were largely decadents of fugitive slaves and other black American immigrants. The parades were marked as a black victory over the British and operated as a military-style event, displaying military regalia, marching bands, and drum corps. Emancipation Day Parades became the most notable displays by and for Black Canadians prior to Caribana. Phillip, Lyndon. “Reading Caribana 1997: Black Youth, Puff Daddy, Style, and Diaspora Transformations” 2007. Beginning in July, the multi-week festivities lead up to the parade which occurs over the long weekend in August which is also known as [[Emancipation Day]], August 1, 1834, in Toronto and [[Simcoe Day]] in Ontario, in honour of [[John Graves Simcoe]], the first Lieutenant-Governor of [[Upper Canada]] who is credited with signing "An Act to Prevent the Further Introduction of Slaves, and to Limit the Terms of Contracts for Servitude Within This Province" (1793). ==Events== Several events occur over the course of the festivities celebrating Caribbean culture. The main stakeholders of the events are the [[Toronto Mas' Bands Association]], the [[Organization of Calypso Performing Artists]], and the [[Ontario Steelpan Association]]. While the Parade of Bands is the most-well known festivities, events include tastes of Caribbean life including exhibits, such as the first Caribana which displayed every book published by a Caribbean writer, including [[Austin Clarke (novelist)|Austin Clarke]] who was the centrepiece of the exhibition; theatre plays, such as Austin Clarke's "Children of the Scheme", which dealt with the plight of Caribbean women who came to Canada on the domestic immigrant worker scheme; and fashion shows. '''Parade of Bands'''
While the Caribbean Festival holds events over several weeks, the culmination of the Caribana event is the final weekend which is punctuated by the street Parade of Bands. This weekend traditionally coincides with the [[civic holiday]] in August. The street Parade of Bands consists of costumed dancers (called "Mas players") along with live [[Caribbean music]] being played from large speakers on the flat-bed of 18 wheeler trucks. Much of the music associated with the event, such as [[steel pan]], [[Soca music|soca]] and [[Calypso music|calypso]], but you can also find floats which play [[Chutney music|chutney]], [[dancehall]] and [[reggae]]. Band leaders start preparation for the following year, the day after the parade ends. As of 2017, [[Whitfield Belasco]] has led a band since his brother recruited him from the Trinidad Carnival to help organize the first Caribana in 1967.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/caribana-caribbean-festival-carnival-funding-toronto-1.4136632|title=50 years later, the beat goes on for the city's Caribbean festival {{!}} CBC News|work=CBC|access-date=2018-03-11|language=en-US}} The bands are the most important part of the main Carnival parade. The bands are actually in competition with one another during the parade. They must pass a judging spot which will rate each band section for its costume design, the energy of masqueraders, the creativity of presentation and so on. Work on the costumes begin soon after the previous year's celebration and usually takes one full year to complete all of the costumes. Bands typically dances to calypso, soca, [[reggae]], [[jazz]], and [[dancehall]]. A King and Queen of the Band is also judged, and winning is considered claiming the biggest prize of the festival. In the 1970s, the parade route originally followed Bloor and Yonge Streets ending at Toronto City Hall concluding with a concert at Nathan Phillips Square.{{cite web|url=http://spacing.ca/toronto/2017/07/31/caribana-meaning-ordered-chaos/ |title=COMMUNITYComments3 Caribana and the meaning of ordered chaos |publisher=Spacing Toronto |accessdate=March 11, 2018}} In the 1980s, the parade ran along Bay and University Avenue. Since 1991, when the parade shifted to Lake Shore Boulevard into Exhibition Place, barricades were introduced to separate the spectators from those [[playing mas]]. File:Centennial College Caribana 090.JPG|Centennial College, 2010 File:Caribana 2010.jpg|Caribana parade, 2010 File:Caribana parade 1.JPG|Caribana parade participants, 2006 '''King and Queen Show'''
The night before the grande para, all the kings and queens (leaders) of the bands compete on stage to be named King and Queen of Carnival. '''Calypso Monarch '''
An event where the Calypso Monarch is crowned. '''Junior Carnival'''
The junior carnival (commonly known as Kiddie Carnival) has run since, at least, the 1990s and provides an opportunity for young masquerades to dance through the streets. Similar to the grand parade, the junior carnival consists of a series of bands with leaders who display costumes in competition. '''J'ouvert'''
In addition to the main parade, the Caribbean community also celebrates a smaller pre-dawn parade known as [[J'ouvert]] (Pronounced "Jou-vay"). This too has been modelled after and taken from [[Trinidad Carnival]]. In Caribbean French-creole this means "day open" or morning. The J'ouvert portion of Carnival is the more rhythmic part of the Carnival celebration and is usually featured with steelpan bands, and persons using improvised musical instruments. It is not usually accompanied by any singing but will have a lot of whistles and other music makers. Spectators and or persons "playing Mas" will occasionally get themselves covered from head-to-toe with mud, flour, baby powder, or different water-colored paints in the tradition of the Caribbean-based J'ouvert celebrations. In many instances, everyone in the band is supposed to resemble evil spirits while parading around at night. There are some common characters{{cite web|url=http://www.visittnt.com/todo/events/Carnival/old_time/default.html |title=Old-Time Carnival Characters (ARCHIVE) |publisher=Trinidad Investment and Development Co. (TIDCO) |accessdate=July 31, 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040907100427/http://www.visittnt.com/todo/events/Carnival/old_time/default.html |archivedate = September 7, 2004}} that are a part of Afro-Caribbean folklore{{cite web|url=http://www.triniview.com/TnT/Soucouyant.htm |title=Trinidad & Tobago's Folklore and Legends The Mayaro Soucouyant (ARCHIVE) |publisher=Paria Publishing |accessdate=July 31, 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20020313062217/http://www.triniview.com/TnT/Soucouyant.htm |archivedate = March 13, 2002}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thedominican.net/articles/soukouyant.htm |author=Fontaine, Thomson|title=Of Myths Folklore and Legends – The Story of Lougarous and Soukouyants |publisher=TheDominican.Net |volume=1| issue= 88|date=December 11, 2006|accessdate=July 31, 2009}} and include things like Red Devils (people covered in red paints), Blue Devils (people covered in blue paints), Green devils, Black devils, Yellow devils, White devils, (usually people throwing baby powder or flour.) or people just covered in other concoctions which are supposed to resemble mud{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yy1k-CgMNBU |title=Artiste: 3 Canal, Song: Mud Madness |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=July 31, 2009}} or oil.{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/cricket/431859723/in/set-72157594276519883/ |title=Photo of some "Blue Devils" during the 2007 Cricket World Cup-In the Caribbean |publisher=Flickr |accessdate=July 31, 2009}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7VeoEmaxjg4 |title=Artiste: 3 Canal, Song: Blue, 1997|publisher=YouTube |accessdate=July 31, 2009}} '''Fêtes'''
Leading up to the main parade a number of Caribbean music artists perform in Toronto. These parties are generally called "[[fête]]s", for a French-Creole Caribbean word meaning "festival", and usually start in June–July. '''Picnics'''
Originally taking place on the [[Toronto Islands]], the island picnics now occur at [[Ontario Place]]. Picnics are two days of feasting on [[roti]]s, [[jerk chicken]] and [[festival]], [[callaloo]], goat head soup, [[potato pudding]], [[pelau]], fried fish, cow foot, [[rum cakes]]; drinking sorrell, Mauby, and [[ginger beer]]; and dancing to music. '''Talk tents'''
Talk tents contain shows featuring storytellers, comedians and others well versed in oral traditions.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/caribana-emc/|title=Toronto Caribbean Carnival (Caribana)|first=Annemarie|last=Gallaugher|date=|website=thecanadianencyclopedia.ca|accessdate=April 22, 2018}} '''Gala'''
The gala, debuted in 2008, is an evening of elegance celebrating Carnival music, arts, and the works of the pioneers of the Caribana festival. ==History== [[File:Scotiabank Toronto Caribbean Carnival.jpg|thumb|right|Scotiabank Toronto Caribbean Carnival logo 2011-2015]] {{Main|History of Caribana (1967–71)}} Caribana has been run annually since 1967, first performed as a gift from Canada's Caribbean community, as a tribute to [[Canadian Centennial|Canada's Centennial]]. Billing itself as a multicultural nation, the Canadian government invited ethno-cultural groups to contribute celebrations with representations of their ethnic diversity.{{Cite journal|last=Jackson|first=Peter|date=|title=The politics of the streets: a geography of Caribana|url=|journal=Political Geography|volume=11|issue=2|pages=130–151|via=}} The name Caribana was invented by the organizers to capture the notions of Canada, the Caribbean, bacchanal and merrymaking. Caribana emerged during a time when many Caribbean residents emigrated to Canada following immigration reform, internationally acclaimed singers, such as [[Harry Belafonte]], was popularizing Caribbean music (in fact, Harry Belafonte sang to a sold out crowd at the [[O'Keefe Centre]] in Toronto), [[Civil Rights Movement]] activities such as [[Malcolm X]] and [[Martin Luther King Jr.]], visited Canadian audiences, and [[Muhammad Ali]] fought against the Canadian heavyweight champion [[George Chuvalo]]. The main Caribana events were run by a [[nonprofit]] Toronto-based organization, the Caribbean Cultural Committee (CCC), its board members mostly made up of expatriate-Caribbean nationals living in Canada. [[Charles Roach]] and [[Julius Iaasc]] (the first Black judge of the Federal Court of Appeal) were among the community leaders who organized the first Caribana. As the festival became a permanent annual event, the festival organization became dependent on borrowing money from the City of Toronto prior to the festival, to be repaid out of festival profits afterwards. By 1992, the festival had built up a significant debt to the City. To aid the festival, the City of Toronto forgave the outstanding debt after the 1992 event.{{cite news|last=Small|first=Peter|title=Caribana expecting bigger profit|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=August 11, 1992|author2=Jane Armstrong|location=Toronto ON|page=A06}} The same year, Caribana developed a new partnership with Toronto-area hotels.{{cite news|last=Henton|first=Darcy|title=Tourism faces new economy|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=May 1, 1993|location=Toronto ON|page=A2}} In 1993, the organization fired its operating chief.{{cite news|title=Caribana fires operating chief|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=May 21, 1993|location=Toronto ON|page=A07}} At launch in [[Nathan Phillips Square]], Premier [[Bob Rae]] calls the event a "beacon of hope" for all Canadians, as a symbol of racial harmony. "Carry a Can to Caribana" launched, in support of [[Daily Bread Food Bank]].{{cite news|last=Wright|first=Lisa|title=Caribana bumps and grinds|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=July 20, 1993|location=Toronto ON|page=A06}} Also in 1993, the Caribana Marketplace covered market was added at [[Marilyn Bell|Marilyn Bell Park]] along the parade route.{{cite news|last=Turnbull|first=Barbara|title=Party time!|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=July 30, 1993|location=Toronto ON|page=A06}} A well-behaved crowd and barricades along the entire parade route contributed to an incident-free parade.{{cite news|title=A million revellers soak up Caribbean beat|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=August 1, 1993|location=Toronto ON|page=A01}} With attendance down, the board chair blamed the federal and provincial tourism ministries for not funding their American advertising campaign.{{cite news|last=MacKinnon|first=Donna Jean|title=Caribana draws grumbles and rave reviews|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=August 5, 1993|location=Toronto ON|page=A06}} In September 2004, after the 37th festival, the [[consul general]] of Trinidad and Tobago pledged to work more closely with Caribbean Cultural Committee to get support for the carnival from the business community; the committee received around {{CAD|1 million}} that year from the national, provincial, and city governments, but it cost about twice that to run the festival.Doyle-Marshall, William, [https://web.archive.org/web/20070926231823/http://www.guardian.co.tt/archives/2004-09-15/bussguardian6.html "The festival for all – Envoy targets Board of Trade to boost Caribana"], ''The Trinidad Guardian'', September 9, 2004. In 2006, the Caribbean Cultural Committee ran into financial troubles again. Because of a lack of financial accountability, the [[City of Toronto]] cut off funding until the organization could get its finances in order. Instead, the funding was given to the Toronto Mas Band Association which had organized the festival in 2002. Due to an ongoing dispute about the ownership of the trademark "Caribana", the 2006 festival was promoted as "the Toronto Caribbean Carnival (Caribana)". In May 2010, the festival added a new initiative to involve post-secondary schools. The only college to participate was [[Centennial College]] School of Hospitality, Tourism and Culture, where they created a costume theme of the Tropical Amazon.{{cite web|author=Centennial College |url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/releases/archive/July2010/27/c6887.html |title=Centennial College students getting into the Caribana spirit |publisher=Newswire.ca |date=July 27, 2010 |accessdate=October 3, 2016}} On September 1, 2010, new management took over the Festival Management Committee (FMC) and named Denise Herrera-Jackson as CEO/Chair of FMC and Chris Alexander as CAO. A naming dispute arose over the use of "Caribana." The Caribbean Cultural Committee claimed that it legally held the [[trademark]] for "Caribana". In April 2010, a panel for the [[World Intellectual Property Organization]] (WIPO) ruled that Scotiabank, as the sponsors of the Caribana festival, did not have grounds for being awarded the domain name caribana.com from its current owners the Working Word Co-operative.{{cite news |title=Scotiabank fails in bid to snag Caribana domain name |author= |first=Omar |last=El Akkad |authorlink= |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/technology/scotiabank-fails-in-bid-to-snag-caribana-domain-name/article1546808/ |agency= |newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] |publisher= |location= |isbn= |issn= |oclc= |pmid= |pmd= |bibcode= |doi= |id= |date=April 26, 2010 |page= |pages= |at= |accessdate=May 9, 2010 |language= |trans-title=|quote=Scotiabank's unsuccessful attempt to gain control of the potentially lucrative website name became the basis for a case before the global tribunal that resolves such domain name disputes – a case that lawyers say could have set a wide-ranging and controversial precedent. |ref= }} In 2011, the Ontario Superior Court Of Justice ruled that the Caribana Arts Group (CAG), the successors of Caribbean Cultural Committee (CCC), has legal rights to the name Caribana. On May 25, 2011, the festival released its new logo and new name, "Scotiabank Caribbean Carnival Toronto".[https://archive.is/20120708080734/http://caribflyer.com/carib/it%E2%80%99s-no-longer-caribana-festival-unveils-its-new-name/ "It’s no longer Caribana: Festival unveils its new name"], Carib101.com, May 25, 2011. In October 2015, Scotiabank announced that it would end its sponsorship with Toronto's Caribbean Carnival parade after six years.{{cite news |url=http://toronto.ctvnews.ca/scotiabank-won-t-renew-sponsorship-of-caribbean-carnival-1.2610963 |title=Scotiabank won't renew sponsorship of Caribbean Carnival |work=CTV News |date=October 2015}} The festival continued without a naming sponsor until 2017 when Peeks became the new title sponsor and the festival became the Peeks Toronto Caribbean Carnival.[https://www.ontariosciencecentre.ca/Media/Details/449/ "Peeks Toronto Caribbean Carnival 2017"], News Release, Ontario Science Centre, June 1, 2017. '''Incidents'''
Incidents have sometimes occurred at the festival, though organizers have long disassociated themselves from the violence. Said [[Lennox Farrell]] in 1992: "We as a board abhor any kind of violence whatsoever. If violence occurs outside a [[Toronto Blue Jays|Blue Jays]] game, it is not ever associated with the Blue Jays game. We wonder why in the mind of the press... that shooting has become associated with Caribana."{{cite news|last=Brent|first=Bob|title=Organizers fear violence might thwart '93 Caribana|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/456460111.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+04%2C+1992&author=Bob+Brent+Toronto+Star&pub=Toronto+Star&desc=Organizers+fear+violence+might+thwart+'93+Caribana&pqatl=google|accessdate=July 31, 2011|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=August 4, 1992|location=Toronto ON|page=A6}} * 1971: A car accident caused parade route deaths and injuries,{{cite news|title=Car kills two children watching parade|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=August 2, 1971|location=Toronto ON|page=1}} and public transit fumbles which led to fighting.{{cite news|title=Free-for-all erupts on jammed TTC bus|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=July 31, 1971|location=Toronto ON|page=1}}; correction issued August 2 issue, page 2. *1993: On July 28, a 29-year-old jumped off a Caribana cruise boat at 11 pm, telling friends that he would meet them on shore at Ontario Place. The [[Trillium (ferry)|''Trillium'']], the boat they were on, was about 300 feet (100 metres) from shore. Police recovered his body on the 30th.{{cite news|title=Body of man, 29, found on bottom of lake|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=July 31, 1993|location=Toronto ON|page=A04}} The victim's mother was hurt by speculation about his sobriety.{{cite news|last=Wright|first=Lisa|title=Police find body of man who leapt from ferry boat|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=August 1, 1993|location=Toronto ON|page=A13}} Another man was stabbed in the finger. A barrier fell at one point, the crowd assisted in bringing them back up. *1996: August 3, 1996: Elrick Christian, 23, was shot and killed and three others, including a nurse visiting from Britain, were wounded during the Caribana parade. Three men were arrested on weapons-related charges after a volley of shots are fired in Marilyn Bell Park beside the parade route. *2011: A man died in a 2011 shooting, while the woman he was with suffered multiple gunshot wounds. putting her in critical condition. Another man was hospitalized after the bullet grazed his eyebrow.{{cite news|last=Hannay|first=Chris|title=One dead, two injured in shooting along Caribbean parade route in Toronto|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/toronto/one-dead-two-injured-in-shooting-along-caribbean-parade-route-in-toronto/article2115517/|accessdate=July 31, 2011|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=July 30, 2011|location=Toronto ON}} ==See also== * [[List of carnivals around the world]] * [[Caribbean music]] * [[Soca music]] * [[Calypso music]] * [[Steelpan]] ==References== ;Citations {{Reflist| colwidth = 30em| refs =}} ==External links== * {{official website|https://torontocarnival.ca/}} {{Commons category|Caribana}} {{Carnival around the world}} {{coord |43.6322|N|79.4169|W|display=title}} [[Category:Afro-Caribbean culture in Canada]] [[Category:Black Canadian culture in Toronto]] [[Category:Caribbean-Canadian culture in Ontario]] [[Category:Music festivals in Toronto]] [[Category:Parades in Canada]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1967]] [[Category:Annual events in Toronto]] [[Category:Carnivals in Canada]] [[Category:August events]] [[Category:Parades in Toronto]] [[Category:July events]]

{{Refimprove|date=December 2014}} '''Carnival blocks''', '''carnaval blocos''' or '''blocos de rua''' are street bands that mobilize crowds on the streets and are the main popular expression of [[Brazilian Carnival]]. These parades fall under the term "street carnival", and happen during a period of about one month, beginning before and finishing after Carnival. Carnaval blocos usually perform [[samba]] music all around Brazil, but other popular musical styles (also identified with Carnaval) are present in specific regions, including [[frevo]] and [[maracatu]] in [[Pernambuco]] and [[axé]] in [[Bahia]].
==In Rio de Janeiro== Street carnival blocos have become a mainstay of Rio's Carnival, and today, there are several hundred blocos. Block parades start in January, and may last until the Sunday after Carnival. Carnaval Blocos are found throughout Rio de Janeiro. One of the largest and oldest blocos is the Cordão do Bola Preta, based in downtown Rio. Other large groups include [[Banda de Ipanema]] and [[Monobloco]].
==In Recife and Olinda== [[File:Bonecos de Olinda - Pernambuco, Brasil.jpg|thumb|Giants dolls of Olinda, Pernambuco]]
In [[Recife]], the carnival block [[Galo da Madrugada]] was registered in the [[Guinness Book of World Records]] as the biggest carnival parade in the world. In its 2013 parade, the crowd following the bloco was larger than 2,500,000 people<ref>http://www.estadao.com.br/noticias/geral,galo-da-madrugada-publico-estimado-de-2-5-milhoes,995344</ref>).
Besides [[Galo da Madrugada]], thousands of others carnival blocks with sizes ranging from few hundred to millions of people, perform in the streets of [[Recife]] and [[Olinda]] including As Virgens de Olinda, Eu Acho É Pouco, Batutas de São José, Lenhadores, Pitombeiras, Segura o Talo, Bloco da Saudade, Enquanto Isso Na Sala de Justiça and Homem da Meia-Noite.
==See also== *[[Samba school]] *[[Sambodromo]]

revision.text:
{{merge from|Herder–farmer conflicts in Nigeria|discuss=Talk:Communal conflicts in Nigeria#Proposed merge with Herder–farmer conflicts in Nigeria|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict = Communal conflicts in Nigeria |partof = |image = Nigeria-karte-politisch english.png |image_size = 300px |caption = Map of the 36 [[States of Nigeria]] |date = 1998–present
({{Age in years, months, weeks and days|year1=1998}}) |place = [[Nigeria]] |status = [[List of ongoing armed conflicts|Ongoing]] |result = |combatant1 = [[Christianity in Nigeria|Christians]] |combatant1a = [[Tiv people|Tiv]] and [[Tarok people|Tarok]] farmers |combatant2 = [[Islam in Nigeria|Muslims]] |combatant2a = [[Fula people|Fulani]] and [[Hausa people|Hausa]] herders |strength1 = |strength2 = |casualties1 = |casualties2 = |casualties3 = 16,000+ people killed since 1998{{cite web|url=http://www.connectsaisafrica.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Table3.htm|title=Social Violence Data Table|publisher= Connect SAIS Africa}} }} '''Communal conflicts in Nigeria'''{{cite web|title=Backgrounder: Communal conflicts in Nigeria|url=https://uppsalaconflictdataprogram.wordpress.com/2012/06/21/backgrounder-communal-conflicts-in-nigeria/|publisher=UCDP|date=21 June 2012}} can be divided into two broad categories:{{cite web|url=http://www.connectsaisafrica.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Nigeria-Social-Violence-Project-Summary_v126.pdf|title=Nigeria Social Violence Project Summary|publisher=[http://www.connectsaisafrica.org/ Connect SAIS Africa]}}{{dubious|date=July 2016}} * [[ethnic conflict]]s, attributed to actors primarily divided by cultural, ethnic, or religious communities and identities, such as instances of [[Religious violence in Nigeria|religious violence between Christian and Muslim communities]] * herder-farmer conflicts, typically involving disputes over land and/or cattle between herders (in particular the [[Fula people|Fulani]] or [[Hausa people|Hausa]]) and farmers (in particular the [[Tiv people|Tiv]] or [[Tarok people|Tarok]]) The most impacted states are those of the Nigerian [[Middle Belt]] like [[Benue State|Benue]], [[Taraba State|Taraba]] and [[Plateau State|Plateau]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/killings-in-benue-plateau-and-taraba-states/211068/|title=KILLINGS IN BENUE, PLATEAU AND TARABA STATES}}
Violence has reached two peaks in 2004 and 2011 with around 2,000 fatalities those years.{{cite web|url=http://www.connectsaisafrica.org/research/african-studies-publications/social-violence-nigeria/|title=Social violence in Nigeria|publisher=Connect SAIS Africa}} It resulted in more than 700 fatalities in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.acleddata.com/data/realtime-data-2015/|title=ACLED Realtime data 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151031092635/http://www.acleddata.com/data/realtime-data-2015/|archivedate=2015-10-31|df=}} ==Herder-farmer conflicts== {{main|Herder–farmer conflicts in Nigeria}} Since the Fourth Nigerian Republic’s founding in 1999, farmer-herder violence has killed thousands of people and displaced tens of thousands more. Insecurity and violence have led many populations to create self-defence forces and ethnic militias, which have engaged in further violence. The majority of farmer-herder clashes have occurred between Muslim [[Fulani herdsmen]] and Christian peasants, exacerbating ethnoreligious hostilities.{{cite web|title=Farmer-Herder Clashes Amplify Challenge for Beleaguered Nigerian Security|url=http://theglobalobservatory.org/2015/07/farmer-herder-nigeria-buhari-abuja-fulani/|publisher=IPI Global Observatory|date=16 July 2015}} ==Other examples== Additional instances of ethnic violence in Nigeria exist;[http://www.ijsr.net/archive/v3i4/MDIwMTMzMTk=.pdf "An Evaluation of the Causes and Efforts Adopted in Managing the Ethnic Conflicts, Identity and Settlement Pattern among the Different Ethnic Groups in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria"], Agbegbedia Oghenevwoke Anthony. ''International Journal of Science and Research'' (''IJSR'') ISSN (Online): 2319-7064 Volume 3 Issue 4, April 2014.{{cite web|author1=ORUMIE S. T.|title=2 NIGER DELTA DEVELOPMENT {{sic|COMMI|SION|hide=y}} (NDDC) AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE OIL PRODUCING COMMUNITIES: A CASE STUDY OF RIVERS STATE|url=http://www.unn.edu.ng/publications/files/images/ORUMIE%20S.%20T.%20NDDC%20AND%20DEVT%20OF%20OIL%20PRODUCING%20COMMUNITIES.pdf|website=University of Nigeria, Nsukka|publisher=[[University of Nigeria, Nsukka]]|accessdate=20 August 2017|date=May 2008}} these are often urban riots or such, for example the Yoruba-Hausa disturbances in Lagos,[http://www.africa.upenn.edu/Newsletters/irinw_8499b.html NIGERIA: Special Report on Ethnic Violence] UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA - AFRICAN STUDIES CENTER.{{cite web |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/978635.stm |title= Lagos calm after city centre riots|accessdate=2007-03-03 |date=2000-10-18|work= BBC Online |publisher=[[BBC]]}} the [[1966 anti-Igbo pogrom|Igbo massacre of 1966]] or the [[Warri Crisis|clashes between the Itsekiri and the Ijaw]] in Delta state. Others are land disputes between neighbours, such as clashes between [[Ile-Ife]] and [[Modakeke]] in the late 1990s[https://www.naij.com/688331-ife-modakeke-clash-guess-oonis-planning.html Ife Modakeke Clash: Guess What Ooni’s Planning] Michael Abimboye, [http://naij.com naij.com] and in Ebonyi State in 2011.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/nigeria/8986941/Nigeria-at-least-50-killed-in-communal-clashes.html/ Nigeria: 'at least 50 killed' in communal clashes.] [[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]], 11:28AM GMT 01 Jan 2012. ==See also== {{Portal|Nigeria}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Religious violence in Nigeria]] * [[List of massacres in Nigeria]] * [[Fulani herdsmen]] * [[List of ongoing armed conflicts]] * [[Sudanese nomadic conflicts]] *[[Warri Crisis]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Suggested reading== *{{cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/This-House-Has-Fallen-Nigeria/dp/0813340454|title=This House Has Fallen: Nigeria in Crisis |first=Karl|last= Maier|edition= illustrated, reprint |publisher=Basic Books|ISBN13=9780813340456|date =December 18, 2002}} ==External links== * [https://uppsalaconflictdataprogram.wordpress.com/2012/06/21/backgrounder-communal-conflicts-in-nigeria/ Communal conflicts in Nigeria] * [http://www.cfr.org/nigeria/nigeria-security-tracker/p29483 Nigeria Security Tracker] * [http://www.acleddata.com/data/version-5-data-1997-2014/ ACLED Data] * [http://www.vanguardngr.com/2015/05/stop-this-massacre-agatu-community-begs-nsa-ig/ Stop this massacre, Agatu Community begs NSA, IG] {{Nigeria topics}} {{Ongoing military conflicts}} {{Post-Cold War African conflicts}} [[Category:Politics of Nigeria]] [[Category:Religion-based civil wars]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2013]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2014]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2015]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2016]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2017]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2018]] [[Category:Ongoing conflicts]] [[Category:Religion-based wars]] [[Category:Conflicts in Nigeria]]

'''Cyber-collection''' refers to the use of [[cyber-warfare]] techniques in order to conduct [[espionage]]. Cyber-collection activities typically rely on the insertion of [[malware]] into a targeted network or computer in order to scan for, collect and exfiltrate sensitive information.
Cyber-collection started as far back as 1996, when widespread deployment of [[Internet connectivity]] to government and corporate systems gained momentum. Since that time, there have been numerous cases of such activity.<ref name="guardian1">Pete Warren, ''[https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2012/aug/30/state-sponsored-cyber-espionage-prevalent State-sponsored cyber espionage projects now prevalent, say experts]'', The Guardian, August 30, 2012</ref><ref name="nytimesfin">Nicole Perlroth, ''[http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/08/13/elusive-finspy-spyware-pops-up-in-10-countries/ Elusive FinSpy Spyware Pops Up in 10 Countries]'', New York Times, August 13, 2012</ref><ref name="AolTech">Kevin G. Coleman, ''[http://gov.aol.com/2012/07/02/has-stuxnet-duqu-and-flame-ignited-a-cyber-arms-race/ Has Stuxnet, Duqu and Flame Ignited a Cyber Arms Race?]'', AOL Government, July 2, 2012</ref>
In addition to the state sponsored examples, cyber-collection has also been used by organized crime for identity and e-banking theft and by corporate spies. [[Operation High Roller]] used cyber-collection agents in order to collect PC and smart-phone information that was used to electronically raid bank accounts.<ref name="HighRoller">Rachael King, ''[https://blogs.wsj.com/cio/2012/06/26/operation-high-roller-targets-corporate-bank-accounts/ Operation High Roller Targets Corporate Bank Accounts]'', June 26, 2012</ref> The [[Rocra]], aka Red October, collection system is an "espionage for hire" operation by organized criminals who sell the collected information to the highest bidder.<ref name="CrunchOctober">Frederic Lardinois, ''[https://techcrunch.com/2013/01/21/eugene-kaspersky-and-mikko-hypponen-talk-red-october-and-the-future-of-cyber-warfare-at-dld/ Eugene Kaspersky And Mikko Hypponen Talk Red October And The Future Of Cyber Warfare At DLD]'', TechCrunch, January 21, 2013</ref><ref name="SundayOctober">Mark Prigg, ''[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2263322/Operation-Red-October-revealed-The-astonishing-hacker-attack-infiltrated-55-000-high-level-government-computers.html The hunt for Red October: The astonishing hacking ring that has infiltrated over 1,000 high level government computers around the world]'', Daily Mail, January 16, 2013</ref>
==Platforms and functionality== Cyber-collection tools have been developed by governments and private interests for nearly every computer and smart-phone operating system. Tools are known to exist for Microsoft, Apple, and Linux computers and iPhone, Android, Blackberry, and Windows phones.<ref name="BloomFinFisher">Vernon Silver, ''[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-08-29/spyware-matching-finfisher-can-take-over-iphone-and-blackberry.html Spyware Matching FinFisher Can Take Over IPhones]'',, Bloomberg, August 29, 2012</ref> Major manufacturers of [[Commercial off-the-shelf]] (COTS) cyber collection technology include Gamma Group from the UK<ref name="finfisher">[http://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120731073430/http://www.finfisher.com/FinFisher/en/index.php FinFisher IT Intrusion]</ref> and [[Hacking Team]] from Italy.<ref name="hackingteam">[http://www.hackingteam.it/index.php/remote-control-system Hacking Team, Remote Control System]</ref> Bespoke cyber-collection tool companies, many offering COTS packages of [[Zero-day attack|zero-day]] exploits, include [[Endgame, Inc.]] and Netragard of the United States and Vupen from France.<ref name="iw">Mathew J. Schwartz, ''[https://www.informationweek.com/security/attacks/weaponized-bugs-time-for-digital-arms-co/240008564 Weaponized Bugs: Time For Digital Arms Control]'', Information Week, 9 October 2012</ref> State intelligence agencies often have their own teams to develop cyber-collection tools, such as [[Stuxnet]], but require a constant source of ''zero-day exploits'' in order to insert their tools into newly targeted systems. Specific technical details of these attack methods often sells for six figure sums.<ref name="slate">Ryan Gallagher, ''[http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/future_tense/2013/01/zero_day_exploits_should_the_hacker_gray_market_be_regulated.html Cyberwar’s Gray Market]'', Slate, 16 Jan 2013</ref>
Common functionality of cyber-collection systems include: *''Data scan'': local and network storage are scanned to find and copy files of interest, these are often documents, spreadsheets, design files such as Autocad files and system files such as the passwd file. *''Capture location'': GPS, WiFi, network information and other attached sensors are used to determine the location and movement of the infiltrated device *''[[Covert listening device|Bug]]'': the device microphone can be activated in order to record audio. Likewise, audio streams intended for the local speakers can be intercepted at the device level and recorded. * ''Hidden Private Networks'' that bypass the corporate network security. A compute that is being spied upon can be plugged into a legitimate corporate network that is heavy monitored for malware activity and at same time belongs to a private wifi network outside of the company network that is leaking confidential information off of an employee's computer. A computer like this is easily set up by a double-agent working in the IT department by install a second Wireless card in a computer and special software to remotely monitor an employee's computer through this second interface card without them being aware of a side-band communication channel pulling information off of his computer. *''Camera'': the device cameras can be activated in order to covertly capture images or video. *''[[Keylogger]] and Mouse Logger'': the malware agent can capture each keystroke, mouse movement and click that the target user makes. Combined with screen grabs, this can be used to obtain passwords that are entered using a virtual on-screen keyboard. *''Screen Grabber'': the malware agent can take periodic screen capture images. In addition to showing sensitive information that may not be stored on the machine, such as e-banking balances and encrypted web mail, these can be used in combination with the key and mouse logger data to determine access credentials for other Internet resources. *''Encryption'': Collected data is usually encrypted at the time of capture and may be transmitted live or stored for later exfiltration. Likewise, it is common practice for each specific operation to use specific encryption and poly-morphic capabilities of the cyber-collection agent in order to ensure that detection in one location will not compromise others. *''Bypass Encryption'': Because the malware agent operates on the target system with all the access and rights of the user account of the target or system administrator, encryption is bypassed. For example, interception of audio using the microphone and audio output devices enables the malware to capture to both sides of an encrypted Skype call.<ref name="Milan">Daniele Milan, [http://www.comm.rtaf.mi.th/Sitedirectory/124/3148/3148_2_6-Daniele-Milan.pdf The Data Encryption Problem], Hacking Team</ref> *''Exfiltration'': Cyber-collection agents usually exfiltrate the captured data in a discrete manner, often waiting for high web traffic and disguising the transmission as secure web browsing. [[USB flash drive]]s have been used to exfiltrate information from [[Air gap (networking)|air gap]] protected systems. Exfiltration systems often involve the use of reverse proxy systems that anonymize the receiver of the data.<ref name="FlameUSB">Robert Lemos, ''[https://www.infoworld.com/t/malware/flame-stashes-secrets-in-usb-drives-195455 Flame stashes secrets in USB drives]'', InfoWorld, June 13, 2012</ref> *''Replicate'': Agents may replicate themselves onto other media or systems, for example an agent may infect files on a writable network share or install themselves onto USB drives in order to infect computers protected by an [[Air gap (networking)|air gap]] or otherwise not on the same network. *''Manipulate Files and File Maintenance'': Malware can be used to erase traces of itself from log files. It can also download and install modules or updates as well as data files. This function may also be used to place "evidence" on the target system, e.g. to insert child pornography onto the computer of a politician or to manipulate votes on an electronic vote counting machine. *''Combination Rules'': Some agents are very complex and are able to combine the above features in order to provide very targeted intelligence collection capabilities. For example, the use of GPS bounding boxes and microphone activity can be used to turn a smart phone into a smart bug that intercepts conversations only within the office of a target. *''Compromised cellphones''. Since, modern cellphones are increasingly similar to general purpose computer, these cellphones are vulnerable to the same cyber-collect attacks as computer systems, and are vulnerable to leak extremely sensitive conversational and location information to an attackers.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=elgj2ZFMZDE how to spy on a cell phone without having access]</ref> Leaking of cellphone GPS location and conversational information to an attacker has been reported in a number of recent [[cyber stalking]] cases where the attacker was able to use the victim's GPS location to call nearby businesses and police authorities to make false allegations against the victim depending on his location, this can range from telling the restaurant staff information to tease the victim, or making false witness against the victim. For instance if the victim were parked in large parking lot the attackers may call and state that they saw drug or violence activity going on with a description of the victim and directions to their GPS location.
==Infiltration== There are several common ways to infect or access the target: *An ''[[Injection Proxy]]'' is a system that is placed upstream from the target individual or company, usually at the Internet service provider, that injects malware into the targets system. For example, an innocent download made by the user can be injected with the malware executable on the fly so that the target system then is accessible to the government agents.<ref name="Gloor">Pascal Gloor, ''[http://www.swinog.ch/meetings/swinog25/p/02_(Un)Lawful%20Intercept%202012-11-07%20SwiNOG25.pdf (Un)lawful Interception] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160205065155/http://www.swinog.ch/meetings/swinog25/p/02_%28Un%29Lawful%20Intercept%202012-11-07%20SwiNOG25.pdf |date=2016-02-05 }}'', SwiNOG #25, 07 November 2012</ref> *''[[Phishing|Spear Phishing]]'': A carefully crafted e-mail is sent to the target in order to entice them to install the malware via a [[Trojan horse (computing)|Trojan]] document or a [[Drive-by download|drive by attack]] hosted on a web server compromised or controlled by the malware owner.<ref name="SpearTechWeb">Mathew J. Schwartz, ''[https://www.informationweek.com/security/attacks/operation-red-october-attackers-wielded/240146621 Operation Red October Attackers Wielded Spear Phishing]'', Information Week, January 16, 2013</ref> *''[[Black bag operation|Surreptitious Entry]]'' may be used to infect a system. In other words, the spies carefully break into the target's residence or office and install the malware on the target's system.<ref name="blackbagfbi">FBI Records: The Vault, ''[http://vault.fbi.gov/Surreptitious%20Entries%20%28Black%20Bag%20Jobs%29%20/ Surreptitious Entries]'', Federal Bureau of Investigation</ref> *An ''Upstream monitor'' or ''[[Packet analyzer|sniffer]]'' is a device that can intercept and view the data transmitted by a target system. Usually this device is placed at the Internet service provider. The [[Carnivore (software)|Carnivore]] system developed by the U.S. [[FBI]] is a famous example of this type of system. Based on the same logic as a [[Lawful Interception|telephone intercept]], this type of system is of limited use today due to the widespread use of encryption during data transmission. *A ''wireless infiltration'' system can be used in proximity of the target when the target is using wireless technology. This is usually a laptop based system that impersonates a WiFi or 3G base station to capture the target systems and relay requests upstream to the Internet. Once the target systems are on the network, the system then functions as an ''Injection Proxy'' or as an ''Upstream Monitor'' in order to infiltrate or monitor the target system. *A ''[[USB flash drive|USB Key]]'' preloaded with the malware infector may be given to or dropped at the target site.
Cyber-collection agents are usually installed by payload delivery software constructed using [[0-day attack|zero-day]] attacks and delivered via infected USB drives, e-mail attachments or malicious web sites.<ref>Kim Zetter, ''[http://www.cnn.com/2012/05/29/tech/web/iran-spyware-flame/index.html "Flame" spyware infiltrating Iranian computers]'', CNN - Wired, May 30, 2012</ref><ref name="DutchUSB">Anne Belle de Bruijn, ''[http://www.elsevier.nl/Tech/nieuws/2012/7/Cybercriminelen-doen-poging-tot-spionage-bij-DSM-ELSEVIER343610W/ Cybercriminelen doen poging tot spionage bij DSM]'', Elsevier, July 9, 2012</ref> State sponsored cyber-collections efforts have used official operating system certificates in place of relying on security vulnerabilities. In the Flame operation, [[Microsoft]] states that the Microsoft certificate used to impersonate a [[Windows Update]] was forged;<ref name="MSCertForged">Mike Lennon, ''[https://www.securityweek.com/microsoft-unauthorized-certificate-was-used-sign-flame-malware Microsoft Certificate Was Used to Sign "Flame" Malware] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130307131239/http://www.securityweek.com/microsoft-unauthorized-certificate-was-used-sign-flame-malware |date=2013-03-07 }}'', June 4, 2012</ref> however, some experts believe that it may have been acquired through [[HUMINT]] efforts.<ref name="MSCertStolen">Paul Wagenseil, ''[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/47675971/ns/technology_and_science-security/t/flame-malware-uses-stolen-microsoft-digital-signature/ Flame Malware Uses Stolen Microsoft Digital Signature]'', NBC News, June 4, 2012</ref>
==Examples of operations== * [[Stuxnet]] * [[Flame (malware)|Flame]] * [[Duqu]] * [[Chaos Computer Club#Staatstrojaner|Bundestrojaner]] * [[Rocra]]<ref name="Rocra">''[https://www.securelist.com/en/analysis/204792262/Red_October_Diplomatic_Cyber_Attacks_Investigation "Red October" Diplomatic Cyber Attacks Investigation]'', Securelist, January 14, 2013</ref><ref name="Kaspersky">''[http://newsroom.kaspersky.eu/fileadmin/user_upload/en/Presskits/090113_Press_Release_Rocra.pdf Kaspersky Lab Identifies Operation Red October]'', Kaspersky Lab Press Release, January 14, 2013</ref> * [[Operation High Roller]]<ref name="HighRollerMcAfee">Dave Marcus & Ryan Cherstobitoff, ''[http://www.mcafee.com/us/resources/reports/rp-operation-high-roller.pdf Dissecting Operation High Roller]'', McAfee Labs</ref>
==See also== * [[Cyberwarfare]] * [[Computer surveillance]] * [[Computer insecurity]] * [[Chinese intelligence operations in the United States]] * [[Cyber-security regulation]] * [[Industrial espionage]] * [[GhostNet]] * [[Proactive Cyber Defence]] * [[Surveillance]] * [[Chaos Computer Club]]<ref name="guardian1" /> * [[Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)]] * [[Tailored Access Operations]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

{{Infobox newspaper | name = East African Business Week | logo = | image = | caption = | type = Weekly newspaper | format = | owners = | founder = | publisher = ''East African Business Week Limited'' | editor = | chiefeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | seniorstaff = | staff = | foundation = 2005 | political = | language = English | ceased publication = | relaunched = | headquarters = 133 Kira Road, [[Kamwookya]]
[[Kampala]], [[Uganda]] | circulation = | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | website = [http://www.busiweek.com/ Homepage] }} '''''East African Business Week''''' is a weekly [[Uganda]]n newspaper published in [[Kampala]], Uganda's capital and largest city. It is the only exclusively business weekly published in the country.{{cite web| url=http://www.preventionweb.net/organizations/9468/profile| title= East African Business Week Limited: Profile|accessdate=22 July 2016| date=22 July 2016| publisher=Preventionweb.net |last=Prevention Web}} ==Location== The newspaper headquarters and main office are located in ''Media Plaza Building'', at 133 Kira Road, in the [[Kamwokya]] neighborhood, in [[Kampala]],{{cite web|accessdate=22 July 2016|date=2014| url=http://www.monitordirectory.co.ug/listing/east-african-business-week-53f540df677b9.html|location=Kampala |title=East African Business Week| publisher=[[Daily Monitor|Monitor Business Directory]]|last=Business Listing}} about {{convert|4.5|km|0}} north of the city's central business district.{{cite web| accessdate=22 July 2016|date=22 July 2016 | url=http://distancecalculator.globefeed.com/Uganda_Distance_Result.asp?fromplace=Post%20Office%20Building%2C%20Kampala%20Road%2C%20Kampala%2C%20Central%20Region%2C%20Uganda&toplace=MEDIA%20PLAZA%2C%20Kira%20Road%2C%20Kampala%2C%20Central%20Region%2C%20Uganda%2C&dt1=ChIJXyfX9IC8fRcRorrkbY-nufI&dt2=ChIJlaKXr6e7fRcRvk4edJLlDbE |title= Distance between Post Office Building, Kampala Road, Kampala, Central Region, Uganda and Media Plaza, Kira Road, Kampala, Central Region, Uganda|publisher=Globefeed.com | author=Globefeed.com}} The coordinates of the newspaper headquarters are 0°20'17.0"N, 32°35'05.0"E (Latitude:0.338053; Longitude:2.584730).{{google maps|title=Location of the Headquarters of East African Business Week|url=https://www.google.com/maps/place/0%C2%B020'17.0%22N+32%C2%B035'05.0%22E/@0.3380547,32.5840564,139m/data=!3m2!1e3!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0x0!8m2!3d0.338053!4d32.58473 |accessdate=22 July 2016}} ==Overview== EABW maintains five bureaus, one in each of the five [[East Africa]]n cities of Kampala, [[Nairobi]], [[Kigali]], [[Bujumbura]], and [[Dar es Salaam]].{{cite web|url=http://www.busiweek.com/index1.php?Ctp=1&pI=1&pLv=1&srI=4&spI=1&cI=1 |title=East African Business Week: About Us| accessdate=22 July 2016 |date=4 September 2008 |publisher=East African Business Week (EABW) |author=EABW |location=Kampala}} The newspaper covers investment and business news, together with health and technology news in [[Burundi]], [[Kenya]], [[Rwanda]], [[Tanzania]], and Uganda. It is published in English only. It has print and Internet versions. ==History== The paper was founded in 2005. It is published by ''East Africa Business Weekly Limited''. ==See also== * [[List of newspapers in Uganda]] * [[Media in Uganda]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.busiweek.com/ Website of East African Business Week] {{DEFAULTSORT:East African Business Week}} [[Category:Kampala]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Uganda]] [[Category:Weekly newspapers]] [[Category:Media in Kampala]] [[Category:Newspapers established in 2005]] [[Category:2005 establishments in Uganda]]
